<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=57,EFW="2190274",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=673457,FOLIO='55',FILE='DISK121:[09ZAL1.09ZAL74201]DT74201A.;25',USER='HYUNG',CD='26-FEB-2009;00:50' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_dv74201_1_56"> </A>


<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"Black" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"font-family:times;" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TABLESHADECOLOR,"#CCEEFF" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_STABLERULES,"border-bottom:solid #000000 1.0pt;" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DTABLERULES,"border-bottom:solid #000000 2.25pt;" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_SCRTABLERULES,"border-bottom:solid #000000 1.0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DCRTABLERULES,"border-bottom:solid #000000 2.25pt;margin-bottom:0pt;" -->



<!-- PARA=JUSTIFY -->
</FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As demonstrated by the tables above, the percentage contribution to operating income and operating margin by each operating segment fluctuated from year to year. Operating income and
operating margin by operating segment were influenced by a variety of factors and events including the following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>In 2008, foreign currency exchange rates favorably impacted operating income by approximately 6&nbsp;percent, primarily
due to a weaker U.S. dollar compared to the euro, Japanese yen and Brazilian real, which had a favorable impact on the Europe, Pacific, Latin America and Bottling Investments operating segments. The
favorable impact of a weaker U.S. dollar compared to the aforementioned currencies was partially offset by the impact of a stronger U.S. dollar compared to the South African rand and the British
pound, which had an unfavorable impact on the Eurasia and Africa, Europe and Bottling Investments operating segments. Refer to the heading "Liquidity, Capital Resources and Financial
Position&#151;Foreign Exchange."  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>In 2008, price increases across the majority of operating segments had a favorable impact on both operating income and
operating margins.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>In 2008, increased spending on marketing and innovation activities impacted the majority of the operating segments'
operating income and operating margins. Refer to the heading "Selling, General and Administrative Expenses," above.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>In 2008, increases in the cost of raw materials and product mix, primarily as a result of finished goods businesses,
adversely impacted North America's operating income and operating margin.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>In 2008, our operating margin was unfavorably impacted by the full year impact of acquisitions made during 2007,
including, but not limited to, 18 German bottling and distribution operations, NORSA, glac&eacute;au, CCBPI and Leao Junior. Refer to the heading "Gross Profit," above. These acquisitions
impacted the Latin America, North America and Bottling Investments operating segments.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>In 2008, operating income was reduced by approximately $1&nbsp;million for Eurasia and Africa, $1&nbsp;million for
Latin America, $56&nbsp;million for North America, $46&nbsp;million for Bottling Investments and $246&nbsp;million for Corporate, primarily due to restructuring costs, contract termination fees,
productivity initiatives and asset impairments. Refer to the heading "Other Operating Charges," above.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>In 2007, foreign currency exchange rates favorably impacted operating income by approximately 4&nbsp;percent, primarily
related to a weaker U.S. dollar compared to the euro, Brazilian real and Australian dollar, which had a favorable impact on the Europe, Latin America and Bottling Investments operating segments. The
favorable impact of a weaker U.S. dollar compared to the aforementioned currencies was partially offset by the impact of a stronger U.S. dollar compared to the Japanese yen and South African rand,
which had an unfavorable impact on the Eurasia and Africa, Pacific and Bottling Investments operating segments. Refer to the heading "Liquidity, Capital Resources and Financial
Position&#151;Foreign Exchange."  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>In 2007, price increases across the majority of operating segments had a favorable impact on both operating income and
operating margins.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>In 2007, increased spending on marketing and innovation activities impacted the majority of the operating segments'
operating income. Refer to the heading "Selling, General and Administrative Expenses," above.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>In 2007, operating income was reduced by approximately $37&nbsp;million for Eurasia and Africa, $33&nbsp;million for
Europe, $4&nbsp;million for Latin America, $23&nbsp;million for North America, $3&nbsp;million for Pacific, $47&nbsp;million for Bottling Investments and $121&nbsp;million for Corporate,
primarily due to restructuring costs and asset impairments, included in other operating charges and cost of goods sold. Refer to the heading "Other Operating Charges," above. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>56</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=58,EFW="2190274",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=75542,FOLIO='56',FILE='DISK121:[09ZAL1.09ZAL74201]DV74201A.;25',USER='HYUNG',CD='26-FEB-2009;00:50' -->
<A NAME="page_dv74201_1_57"> </A>
<UL>
<UL>
</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>In 2007, operating income and operating margin for Latin America, North America and Pacific reflected the impact of
increases in the cost of raw materials primarily in the finished goods businesses.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>In 2007, operating income and operating margin for Bottling Investments reflected the impact of acquisitions and the
consolidation of certain bottling operations. Refer to the heading "Gross Profit," above.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>In 2006, operating income was reduced by approximately $3&nbsp;million for Eurasia and Africa, $36&nbsp;million for
Europe, $62&nbsp;million for Pacific, $87&nbsp;million for Bottling Investments and $1&nbsp;million for Corporate primarily due to contract termination fees related to production capacity
efficiencies, asset impairments and other restructuring costs. Refer to the heading "Other Operating Charges," above.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>In 2006, operating income was reduced by $100&nbsp;million for Corporate as a result of a donation made to The
Coca-Cola Foundation. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Interest Income and Interest Expense  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Company monitors our mix of fixed-rate and variable-rate debt as well as our mix of short-term
debt versus long-term debt. This monitoring includes a review of business and other financial risks. From time to time, we enter into interest rate swap agreements and other related
instruments to manage our mix of fixed-rate and variable-rate debt. Refer to Note&nbsp;11 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest
income increased by $97&nbsp;million in 2008 compared to 2007. This increase was primarily due to higher average short-term investment balances, partially offset
by lower interest rates. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest
expense decreased by $18&nbsp;million in 2008 compared to 2007. This decrease was primarily attributable to lower interest rates on short-term debt and a net
benefit of approximately $8&nbsp;million related to the reclassification of gains and losses on interest rate locks from AOCI to interest expense. This net benefit consisted of approximately
$17&nbsp;million of previously unrecognized gains related to cash flow hedges that were discontinued during the second quarter of 2008, as it was no longer probable that we would issue the
long-term debt for which these hedges were designated, which was partially offset by approximately $9&nbsp;million of losses related to the portion of cash flow hedges that were deemed
to be ineffective during 2008. The favorable impact of aforementioned items was partially offset by the impact of higher average short-term and long-term debt balances. We
expect net interest expense to increase in 2009 due to forecasted higher debt balances. Refer to the heading "Liquidity, Capital Resources and Financial Position." </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2007, interest income increased by $43&nbsp;million compared to 2006, primarily due to higher average short-term investment balances, partially offset by a decline in
interest rates. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest
expense in 2007 increased by $236&nbsp;million compared to 2006, primarily due to issuance of $1,750&nbsp;million of notes due November&nbsp;15, 2017, and higher average
balances on commercial paper borrowings in the U.S., partially offset by a decline in interest rates. The net proceeds of approximately $1,747&nbsp;million from this long-term debt
issuance and the increase in commercial paper borrowings were primarily used to finance 2007 acquisitions. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Equity Income (Loss)&#151;Net  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Equity income (loss)&#151;net represents our Company's proportionate share of net income or loss from each of our equity method
investments. In 2008, equity income (loss)&#151;net was an equity loss of approximately $874&nbsp;million compared to equity income of approximately $668&nbsp;million in 2007, a decrease of
$1,542&nbsp;million. This decrease was primarily attributable to impairment charges recorded by CCE during 2008, of which our Company's proportionate share was approximately $1.6&nbsp;billion.
Refer to the heading "Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates&#151;Goodwill, Trademarks and Other Intangible Assets" and Note&nbsp;3 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. In
addition to our proportionate share of the charges discussed above, the Company recorded charges of approximately $60&nbsp;million to equity income (loss)&#151;net, primarily related to our </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>57</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=59,EFW="2190274",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=858256,FOLIO='57',FILE='DISK121:[09ZAL1.09ZAL74201]DV74201A.;25',USER='HYUNG',CD='26-FEB-2009;00:50' -->
<A NAME="page_dv74201_1_58"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>proportionate
share of restructuring charges and asset impairments recorded by certain equity method investees. Refer to Note&nbsp;3 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. The impact of
these charges was partially offset by our proportionate share of increased net income from certain of our equity method investees, which included the favorable impact of foreign exchange fluctuations. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2007, equity income (loss)&#151;net was an equity income of approximately $668&nbsp;million compared to $102&nbsp;million in 2006, an increase of $566&nbsp;million. This
increase was primarily attributable to an impairment charge recorded by CCE during 2006, of which our Company's proportionate share was approximately $602&nbsp;million. Refer to heading "Critical
Accounting Policies and Estimates&#151;Goodwill, Trademarks and Other Intangible Assets," and Note&nbsp;3 and Note&nbsp;19 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. Additionally, the
increase in 2007 also reflected our proportionate share of increased net income from certain of our equity method investees as a result of the overall improving health of the Coca-Cola
bottling system in most of the world, our proportionate share of tax benefits recorded by CCE and the favorable impact of foreign currency fluctuations. The favorable impact of these items was
partially offset by our proportionate share of impairment charges recorded by Coca-Cola Amatil, restructuring charges recorded by CCE, the write-off of excess bottles and cases
at CCBPI and the net impact of acquisitions and divestitures of equity method investments during 2007 and 2006. Refer to Note&nbsp;3 and Note&nbsp;20 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Other Income (Loss)&#151;Net  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other income (loss)&#151;net includes, among other things, the impact of foreign exchange gains and losses, dividend income,
rental income, gains and losses related to the
disposal of property, plant and equipment, realized and unrealized gains and losses on trading securities, realized gains and losses on available-for-sale securities,
other-than-temporary impairments of available-for-sale securities, the accretion of expense related to certain acquisitions and minority shareowners'
proportionate share of net income of certain consolidated subsidiaries. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2008, other income (loss)&#151;net was a loss of $28&nbsp;million. The Company recognized other-than-temporary impairment charges of approximately
$81&nbsp;million on available-for-sale securities. Refer to the heading "Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates&#151;Investments in Equity and Debt Securities" and
Note&nbsp;10 and Note&nbsp;19 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. Other income (loss)&#151;net also included approximately $46&nbsp;million of realized and unrealized losses on
trading securities. These losses, along with other charges that were not individually significant, were partially offset by gains on divestitures of approximately $119&nbsp;million, primarily
related to the sale of Remil to Coca-Cola FEMSA and the sale of a portion of the Company's investment in Coca-Cola Pakistan to Coca-Cola Icecek A.S.
("Coca-Cola Icecek"). Refer to Note&nbsp;3 and Note&nbsp;19 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2007, other income (loss)&#151;net was income of $173&nbsp;million. The Company recognized a gain of approximately $73&nbsp;million due to the sale of a portion of the
Company's ownership interest in Coca-Cola Amatil. As a result of this transaction, our ownership interest in Coca-Cola Amatil was reduced from approximately 32&nbsp;percent
to 30&nbsp;percent. In addition, we recognized a gain of approximately $70&nbsp;million as a result of the sale of our equity investment in Vonpar Refrescos&nbsp;S.A. ("Vonpar") and gains of
approximately $84&nbsp;million due to the sale of real estate in Spain and the United States. Refer to Note&nbsp;3 and Note&nbsp;19 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2006, other income (loss)&#151;net was income of $195&nbsp;million, primarily attributable to a gain of approximately $175&nbsp;million as a result of the sale of a portion
of our Coca-Cola FEMSA shares to FEMSA and a gain of approximately $123&nbsp;million due to the sale of a portion of our investment in Coca-Cola Icecek shares in an initial
public offering. These gains were partially offset by the accretion of approximately $58&nbsp;million of expense related to the discounted value of our liability to purchase Coca-Cola
Erfrischungsgetraenke AG ("CCEAG") shares and approximately $15&nbsp;million in foreign currency exchange losses. Refer to Note&nbsp;3 and Note&nbsp;19 of Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>58</FONT></P>

<A NAME="page_dv74201_1_59"> </A>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Income Taxes  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our effective tax rate reflects tax benefits derived from significant operations outside the United States, which are generally taxed
at rates lower than the U.S. statutory rate of 35&nbsp;percent. A change in the mix of pretax income from these various tax jurisdictions can have a significant impact on the Company's periodic
effective tax rate. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
effective tax rate of approximately 21.9&nbsp;percent for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008, included the following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>an approximate 20&nbsp;percent combined effective tax rate on restructuring charges,
other-than-temporary impairments of available-for-sale securities, contract termination fees, productivity initiatives and asset impairments recorded by
the Company (refer to Note&nbsp;18 and Note&nbsp;19 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements);  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>an approximate 23&nbsp;percent combined effective tax rate on our proportionate share of asset impairment and
restructuring charges recorded by equity method investees, primarily related to impairment charges recorded by CCE (refer to Note&nbsp;3 and Note&nbsp;19 of Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements);  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>an approximate 24&nbsp;percent combined effective tax rate on gains from divestitures (refer to Note&nbsp;19 of Notes
to Consolidated Financial Statements);  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>a tax charge of approximately $10&nbsp;million related to the recognition of a valuation allowance on deferred tax
assets (refer to Note&nbsp;17 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements); and  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>a net tax benefit of approximately $5&nbsp;million, primarily related to amounts required to be recorded for changes to
our uncertain tax positions under Interpretation No.&nbsp;48, including interest and penalties (refer to Note&nbsp;17 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements). </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
effective tax rate of approximately 24.0&nbsp;percent for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007, included the following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>an approximate 18&nbsp;percent combined effective tax rate on restructuring charges and asset impairments recorded by
the Company (refer to Note&nbsp;18 and Note&nbsp;19 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements);  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>an approximate 14&nbsp;percent combined effective tax rate on our proportionate share of restructuring charges and tax
rate changes recorded by CCE, and asset impairments recorded by CCBPI and Coca-Cola Amatil (refer to Note&nbsp;19 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements); </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>an approximate 58&nbsp;percent combined effective tax rate on the sale of a portion of our equity interest in
Coca-Cola Amatil and Vonpar (refer to Note&nbsp;19 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements);  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>a tax benefit of approximately $19&nbsp;million related to tax rate changes in Germany (refer to Note&nbsp;17 of Notes
to Consolidated Financial Statements); and  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>a tax charge of approximately $96&nbsp;million related to amounts required to be recorded for changes to our uncertain
tax positions under Interpretation No.&nbsp;48, including interest and penalties (refer to Note&nbsp;17 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements). </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
effective tax rate of approximately 22.8&nbsp;percent for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, included the following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>an approximate 16&nbsp;percent combined effective tax rate on asset impairments, impairments of investments in our
bottling operations, contract termination fees and restructuring charges recorded by the Company (refer to Note&nbsp;19 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements); </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>59</FONT></P>

<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_dv74201_1_60"> </A>
<UL>
<UL>
</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>an approximate 8.8&nbsp;percent net effective tax rate on our proportionate share of impairment charges, restructuring
charges and the impact of certain tax rate changes recorded by CCE (refer to Note&nbsp;3 and Note&nbsp;19 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements);  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>an approximate 1.8&nbsp;percent tax benefit on the sale of a portion of our investments in Coca-Cola Icecek
and Coca-Cola FEMSA. The tax benefit was a result of the reversal of valuation allowances on certain deferred tax assets recorded related to capital loss carryforwards. In addition to the
impact of the reversal of valuation allowances, we also benefited from the reversal of deferred tax liabilities related to differences between the book and tax bases in the stock sold. The tax benefit
associated with the aforementioned items was partially offset by a reduction of deferred tax assets due to the utilization of these capital loss carryforwards. The capital loss carryforwards offset
the taxable gain on the sale of a portion of our investments in Coca-Cola Icecek and Coca-Cola FEMSA (refer to Note&nbsp;19 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements);
and  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>a tax charge of approximately $24&nbsp;million related to the resolution of certain tax matters (refer to Note&nbsp;17
of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements). </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company adopted the provisions of Interpretation No.&nbsp;48 effective January&nbsp;1, 2007. As a result of the implementation of Interpretation No.&nbsp;48, the Company
recorded an increase of approximately $65&nbsp;million in liabilities for unrecognized tax benefits, which was accounted for as a reduction to the January&nbsp;1, 2007, balance of reinvested
earnings. As of December&nbsp;31, 2007, the Company had recorded gross unrecognized tax benefits of approximately $643&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2008, agreements were reached between the U.S. government and a foreign government concerning the allocation of income between the two tax jurisdictions. Pursuant to these agreements,
we made cash payments during the third quarter of 2008 that constituted payments of tax and interest. These payments were partially offset by tax credits taken in the third quarter and fourth quarter
of 2008, and tax refunds and interest on refunds to be received in 2009. These benefits had been recorded as deferred tax assets in prior periods. The settlements did not have a material impact on the
Company's consolidated income statement
for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008. The impact of these agreements, and other 2008 activity, is reflected in the balances of our unrecognized tax benefits and deferred tax assets as of
December&nbsp;31, 2008, which are further discussed below. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;31, 2008, the gross amount of unrecognized tax benefits was approximately $369&nbsp;million. If the Company were to prevail on all uncertain tax positions, the
net effect would be a benefit to the Company's effective tax rate of approximately $174&nbsp;million. The remaining approximately $195&nbsp;million, which was recorded as a deferred tax asset,
primarily represents tax benefits that would be received in different tax jurisdictions in the event that the Company did not prevail on all uncertain tax positions. The Company recognizes accrued
interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits in income tax expense. The Company had approximately $110&nbsp;million in interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits
accrued as of December&nbsp;31, 2008. If the Company were to prevail on all uncertain tax positions, the reversal of this accrual would also be a benefit to the Company's effective tax rate. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Based
on current tax laws, the Company's effective tax rate in 2009 is expected to be approximately 23.0&nbsp;percent to 24.0&nbsp;percent before considering the effect of any
unusual or special items that may affect our tax rate in future years. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Liquidity, Capital Resources and Financial Position  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We believe our ability to generate cash from operating activities is one of our fundamental financial strengths. The
near-term outlook for our business remains strong and we expect to generate substantial cash flows from operations in 2009. As a result of our expected strong cash flows from operations,
we have significant flexibility to meet our financial commitments. We typically fund a significant portion of our dividends, capital expenditures, contractual obligations, share repurchases and
acquisitions with cash generated from operating </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>60</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=62,EFW="2190274",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=959182,FOLIO='60',FILE='DISK121:[09ZAL1.09ZAL74201]DV74201A.;25',USER='HYUNG',CD='26-FEB-2009;00:50' -->
<A NAME="page_dv74201_1_61"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>activities.
We rely on external funding for additional cash requirements. The Company does not typically raise capital through the issuance of stock, instead, we use debt financing to lower our
overall cost of capital and increase our return on shareowners' equity. Refer to the heading "Cash Flows from Financing Activities&#151;Debt Financing," below. Our debt financing includes the
use of an extensive commercial paper program as part of our overall cash management strategy. Despite the recent disruption to the general credit markets, our liquidity remains strong, and our
commercial paper program continues to function each day. We are able to access 60- to 90-day terms and have not had a material change to our spreads to benchmark rates;
however, there is no assurance that this will not change in the future. The Company is reviewing its optimal mix of short-term and long-term debt. We may replace a certain
amount of commercial paper and short-term debt with longer-term debt in the future. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
September&nbsp;3, 2008, we announced our intention to make cash offers to purchase China Huiyuan Juice Group Limited, a Hong Kong listed company which owns the Huiyuan juice
business throughout China ("Huiyuan"). Assuming full acceptance of the offers, the transaction is valued at approximately $2.4&nbsp;billion. Refer to the heading "Additional Information." Due to
this pending transaction, the Company curtailed its share repurchase program during the fourth quarter of 2008, and does not anticipate repurchasing shares during 2009. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
significant decline in the equity markets precipitated by the recent credit crisis and financial system instability has negatively affected the value of our pension plan assets. As a
result of the decline in fair value of our pension plan assets, we have made and will consider making additional contributions to our U.S. and international pension plans in 2009. Refer to the heading
"Aggregate Contractual Obligations" and Note&nbsp;16 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for further discussion. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
majority of the Company's cash is held by our international subsidiaries. We have reviewed our contingency plans and would be able to access cash held by our international
subsidiaries on short notice. Our approximate $4.7&nbsp;billion cash balance as of December&nbsp;31, 2008, is available and held in liquid, high-quality cash equivalent investments.
However, in the event that we required the use of cash held by our international subsidiaries for an extended period of time in the United States, we would be required to treat the cash as having been
repatriated and we would incur significant tax liabilities. Refer to the heading "Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates&#151;Income Taxes," above. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition to the Company's cash balances and commercial paper program, we also maintain $2.6&nbsp;billion of committed, currently unused credit facilities from our network of
relationship banks. These backup lines of credit expire at various times from 2009 through 2013. We have evaluated the financial stability of each bank and believe we can access the funds, if needed.
Refer to Note&nbsp;7 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Based
on all of these factors, the Company believes its current liquidity position is strong, and we will continue to meet all of our financial commitments for the foreseeable future. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Cash Flows from Operating Activities  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net cash provided by operating activities for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008, 2007 and 2006 was approximately
$7,571&nbsp;million, $7,150&nbsp;million and $5,957&nbsp;million, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
flows from operating activities increased $421&nbsp;million, or 6&nbsp;percent, in 2008 compared to 2007. This increase was primarily attributable to increased cash collections
from customers, driven by the 11&nbsp;percent increase in net operating revenues. Refer to heading "Operations Review&#151;Net Operating Revenues." </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
impact of increased cash collections from customers was partially offset by increased payments to suppliers and vendors, increased payments for selling, general and administrative
expenses and an increase in tax payments. The increase in payments to suppliers and vendors was primarily attributable to higher sales volume and increased marketing and advertising costs to support
our brands. The increase in tax payments included payments associated with the agreement between the U.S. government and a foreign government. Refer to the heading "Operations
Review&#151;Income Taxes" and Note&nbsp;17 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>61</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=63,EFW="2190274",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=768312,FOLIO='61',FILE='DISK121:[09ZAL1.09ZAL74201]DV74201A.;25',USER='HYUNG',CD='26-FEB-2009;00:50' -->
<A NAME="page_dv74201_1_62"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Additionally,
the Company made approximately $224&nbsp;million in payments related to streamlining activities and the costs of productivity initiatives during 2008. Refer to Note&nbsp;18 of Notes
to Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
May&nbsp;26, 2008, the Company and the other defendants reached an agreement with the plaintiffs in a class action lawsuit (</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Carpenters Health&nbsp;&amp;
Welfare Fund of Philadelphia&nbsp;&amp; Vicinity v. The Coca-Cola Company, et al.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>) to settle the lawsuit for approximately $138&nbsp;million, without admitting any
wrongdoing. The settlement amount was covered by insurance and, therefore, the settlement had no impact on our consolidated statement of income. The payments related to this settlement were made
directly from the insurers to the plaintiffs during the third quarter and fourth quarter of 2008. As a result, the settlement had no impact on our consolidated statement of cash flows. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
flows from operating activities increased $1,193&nbsp;million, or 20&nbsp;percent, in 2007 compared to 2006. This increase was primarily related to increased cash receipts from
customers in 2007, which was driven by a 20&nbsp;percent rise in net operating revenues. These higher cash collections were offset in part by increased payments to suppliers and vendors in 2007,
primarily related to the increased cost of goods sold to support the higher sales volumes, and secondarily related to higher cash payments for selling, general and administrative related costs. Cash
flows from operating activities in 2007 were also reduced due to an increase in interest payments of $193&nbsp;million and an increase in cash payments for streamlining initiatives of
$83&nbsp;million. Cash flows from operating activities in 2006 included the impact of increased tax payments made related to repatriation of foreign earnings under The American Jobs Creation Act of
2004, a contribution of approximately $216&nbsp;million to a U.S. Voluntary Employee Beneficiary Association ("VEBA"), a tax-qualified trust to fund retiree medical benefits and a
$100&nbsp;million donation made to The Coca-Cola Foundation. Refer to Note&nbsp;16 and Note&nbsp;19 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for additional information on the
contribution to a VEBA. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash used in investing activities included acquisitions and investments of approximately $759&nbsp;million in 2008, $5,653&nbsp;million in
2007 and $901&nbsp;million in 2006. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2008, the Company's acquisition and investment activities included the acquisition of brands and licenses in Denmark and Finland from Carlsberg for approximately $225&nbsp;million.
None of the other acquisitions during 2008 was individually significant. Refer to Note&nbsp;20 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investing
activities during 2008 also included proceeds of approximately $275&nbsp;million, net of the cash balance as of the disposal date, related to the sale of Remil to
Coca-Cola FEMSA. Refer to Note&nbsp;3 and Note&nbsp;19 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2007, our Company acquired glac&eacute;au, 18 German bottling and distribution operations, Fuze Beverage,&nbsp;LLC ("Fuze") and Leao Junior. Our Company also completed the
acquisition of the remaining </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>62</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=64,EFW="2190274",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=720101,FOLIO='62',FILE='DISK121:[09ZAL1.09ZAL74201]DV74201A.;25',USER='HYUNG',CD='26-FEB-2009;00:50' -->
<A NAME="page_dv74201_1_63"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>65&nbsp;percent
of the shares of capital stock of CCBPI not previously owned by our Company. In addition, the Company acquired a 50&nbsp;percent interest in Jugos del Valle, a 34&nbsp;percent
interest in Tokyo Coca-Cola Bottling Company ("Tokyo CCBC") and an 11&nbsp;percent interest in NORSA. Refer to Note&nbsp;20 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. The remaining
amount of cash used for acquisitions and investments was primarily related to the acquisition of various trademarks and brands, none of which was individually significant. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investing
activities in 2007 also included proceeds of approximately $238&nbsp;million received from the sale of our 49&nbsp;percent equity interest in Vonpar, approximately
$143&nbsp;million received from the sale of a portion of our interest in Coca-Cola Amatil, and approximately $106&nbsp;million in proceeds from the sale of real estate in Spain and in
the United States. Refer to Note&nbsp;19 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2006, our Company acquired a controlling interest in CCCIL and acquired Apollinaris and TJC Holdings (Pty)&nbsp;Ltd., a South African bottling company ("TJC"). Refer to
Note&nbsp;20 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. The remaining amount of cash used for acquisitions and investments was primarily related to the acquisition of various trademarks and
brands, none of which was individually significant. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investing
activities in 2006 also included proceeds of approximately $198&nbsp;million received from the sale of shares in connection with the initial public offering of
Coca-Cola Icecek and proceeds of approximately $427&nbsp;million received from the sale of a portion of Coca-Cola FEMSA shares to FEMSA. Refer to Note&nbsp;3 of Notes to
Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
purchases of property, plant and equipment for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008, 2007 and 2006 were approximately $1,839&nbsp;million, $1,409&nbsp;million and
$1,295&nbsp;million, respectively. These increases were primarily related to acquisitions of certain bottling operations in 2007 and 2006. Refer to Note&nbsp;20 of Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements. Generally, bottling and finished product operations are more capital intensive compared to concentrate and syrup operations. Additionally, the impact of foreign currency fluctuations
during 2008 also contributed to the increase in reported purchases of property, plant and equipment. Refer to the heading "Foreign Exchange," below. Our Company currently estimates that net purchases
of property, plant and equipment in 2009 will be approximately $1.8&nbsp;billion to $2.0&nbsp;billion. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total
capital expenditures for property, plant and equipment (including our investments in information technology) and the percentage of such totals by operating segment for 2008, 2007
and 2006 were as follows: </FONT></P>

<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>)</B></FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2> $&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;973</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2> $&nbsp;&nbsp;(6,583</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>)</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size:1.5pt;" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=11 style="font-family:times;border-bottom:solid #000000 2.25pt;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Debt Financing  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Company maintains debt levels we consider prudent based on our cash flows, interest coverage ratio and percentage of debt to
capital. We use debt financing to lower our overall cost of capital, which increases our return on shareowners' equity. This exposes us to adverse changes in interest rates. Our interest expense may
also be affected by our credit ratings. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;31, 2008, our long-term debt was rated "A+" by Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's and "Aa3" by Moody's, and our commercial paper program was rated
"A-1" and "P-1" by Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's and Moody's, respectively. In assessing our credit strength, both Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's and Moody's consider our capital
structure (including the amount and maturity dates of our debt) and financial policies as well as the aggregated balance sheet and other financial information for the Company and certain bottlers,
including CCE and Coca-Cola Hellenic. While the Company has no legal obligation for the debt of these bottlers, the rating agencies believe the strategic importance of the bottlers to the
Company's business model provides the Company with an incentive to keep these bottlers viable. It is our expectation that the credit rating agencies will continue using this methodology. If our credit
ratings were to be downgraded as a result of changes in our capital structure, our major bottlers' financial performance, changes in the credit rating agencies' methodology in assessing our credit
strength or for any other reason, our cost of borrowing could increase. Additionally, if certain bottlers' credit ratings were to decline, the Company's share of equity income could be reduced as a
result of the potential increase in interest expense for these bottlers. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
October 2008, Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's affirmed the Company's A+ long-term debt rating, but revised its outlook from stable to negative. Moody's rating of Aa3 for the
Company's long-term debt remains on negative outlook, where it has been since 2001. The Company does not believe that a downgrade by either agency would have a material adverse effect on
the cost of borrowing. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
monitor our interest coverage ratio and, as indicated above, the rating agencies consider our ratio in assessing our credit ratings. However, the rating agencies aggregate financial
data for certain bottlers along with our Company when assessing our debt rating. As such, the key measure to rating agencies is the
aggregate interest coverage ratio of the Company and certain bottlers. Both Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's and Moody's employ different aggregation methodologies and have different thresholds for the
aggregate interest coverage ratio. These thresholds are not necessarily permanent, nor are they fully disclosed to our Company. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
global presence and strong capital position give us access to key financial markets around the world, enabling us to raise funds at a low effective cost. This posture, coupled with
active management of our mix of short-term and long-term debt and our mix of fixed-rate and variable-rate debt, results in a lower overall cost of
borrowing. Our debt management policies, in conjunction with our share repurchase programs and investment activity, can result in current liabilities exceeding current assets. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>64</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=66,EFW="2190274",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=876357,FOLIO='64',FILE='DISK121:[09ZAL1.09ZAL74201]DV74201A.;25',USER='HYUNG',CD='26-FEB-2009;00:50' -->
<A NAME="page_dv74201_1_65"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Issuances
and payments of debt included both short-term and long-term financing activities. On December&nbsp;31, 2008, we had approximately
$3,462&nbsp;million in lines of credit and other short-term credit facilities available, of which approximately $677&nbsp;million was outstanding. This outstanding amount was primarily
related to our international operations. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
issuances of debt in 2008 included approximately $4,001&nbsp;million of issuances of commercial paper and short-term debt with maturities of greater than
90&nbsp;days, and approximately $194&nbsp;million of net issuances of commercial paper and short-term debt with maturities of 90&nbsp;days or less. The payments of debt in 2008
included approximately $4,032&nbsp;million related to commercial paper and short-term debt with maturities of greater than 90&nbsp;days. The Company continues to review its optimal mix
of short-term and long-term debt. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
issuances of debt in 2007 included approximately $6,024&nbsp;million of issuances of commercial paper and short-term debt with maturities of greater than
90&nbsp;days, approximately $1,750&nbsp;million in issuances of long-term notes due November&nbsp;15, 2017, and approximately $2,024&nbsp;million of net issuances of commercial
paper and short-term debt with maturities of 90&nbsp;days or less. The increase in debt was primarily due to 2007 acquisitions. Refer to Note&nbsp;20 of Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements. During the fourth quarter of 2007, the Company replaced a certain amount of commercial paper and short-term debt with longer-term debt. Refer to Note&nbsp;8 of
Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. The payments of debt in 2007 included approximately $5,514&nbsp;million related to commercial paper and short-term debt with maturities of
greater than 90&nbsp;days. Included in these payments was the payment of the outstanding liability to CCEAG shareowners in January 2007 of $1,068&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
issuances of debt in 2006 included approximately $484&nbsp;million of issuances of commercial paper and short-term debt with maturities of greater than 90&nbsp;days.
The payments of debt in 2006 included approximately $580&nbsp;million related to commercial paper and short-term debt with maturities of greater than 90&nbsp;days and approximately
$1,383&nbsp;million of net repayments of commercial paper and short-term debt with maturities of 90&nbsp;days or less. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Issuances of Stock  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The issuances of stock in 2008, 2007 and 2006 primarily related to the exercise of stock options by Company employees. In addition,
during 2007, certain executive officers and former shareholders of glac&eacute;au invested approximately $179&nbsp;million of their proceeds from the sale of glac&eacute;au in common
stock of the Company at then current market prices. These shares of Company common stock were placed in escrow pursuant to the glac&eacute;au acquisition agreement. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Share Repurchases  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In October 1996, our Board of Directors authorized a plan ("1996 Plan") to repurchase up to 206&nbsp;million shares of our Company's
common stock through 2006. On July&nbsp;20, 2006, the Board of Directors of the Company authorized a new share repurchase program of up to 300&nbsp;million shares of the Company's common stock.
The new program took effect upon the expiration of the 1996 Plan on October&nbsp;31, 2006. The table below presents annual shares repurchased and average price per share: </FONT></P>

approximately 1.3&nbsp;billion shares of our Company's common stock at an average price per share of $19.02. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company curtailed its share repurchase program during the fourth quarter of 2008. Additionally, as a result of the pending acquisition of Huiyuan, the Company does not anticipate
repurchasing shares during 2009. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Dividends  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At its February 2009 meeting, our Board of Directors increased our quarterly dividend by 8&nbsp;percent, raising it to $0.41 per
share, equivalent to a full year dividend of $1.64 per share in 2009. This is our 47<SUP>th</SUP>&nbsp;consecutive annual increase. Our annual common stock dividend was $1.52 per share, $1.36 per
share and $1.24 per share in 2008, 2007 and 2006, respectively. The 2008 dividend represented a 12&nbsp;percent increase from 2007, and the 2007 dividend represented a 10&nbsp;percent increase
from 2006. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements and Aggregate Contractual Obligations  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In accordance with the definition under SEC rules, the following qualify as off-balance sheet
arrangements: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>any obligation under certain guarantee contracts;  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>a retained or contingent interest in assets transferred to an unconsolidated entity or similar arrangement that serves as
credit, liquidity or market risk support to that entity for such assets;  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>any obligation under certain derivative instruments; and  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>any obligation arising out of a material variable interest held by the registrant in an unconsolidated entity that
provides financing, liquidity, market risk or credit risk support to the registrant, or engages in leasing, hedging or research and development services with the registrant. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;31, 2008, we were contingently liable for guarantees of indebtedness owed by third parties in the amount of approximately $238&nbsp;million. These guarantees
primarily are related to third-party customers, bottlers and vendors and have arisen through the normal course of business. These guarantees have various terms, and none of these guarantees was
individually significant. The amount represents the maximum potential future payments that we could be required to make under the guarantees; however, we do not consider it probable that we will be
required to satisfy these guarantees. Management concluded that the
likelihood of any material amounts being paid by our Company under these guarantees is not probable. As of December&nbsp;31, 2008, we were not directly liable for the debt of any unconsolidated
entity, and we did not have any retained or contingent interest in assets as defined above. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
Company recognizes all derivatives as either assets or liabilities at fair value in our consolidated balance sheets. Refer to Note&nbsp;11 of Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>66</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<TD COLSPAN=17 style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-top:12pt;margin-left:11pt;text-indent:-11pt;"><FONT SIZE=2> <SUP>1</SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Refer to Note&nbsp;7 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for information regarding short-term loans and
notes payable. Upon payment of outstanding commercial paper, we typically issue new commercial paper. Lines of credit and other short-term borrowings are expected to fluctuate depending upon current liquidity needs, especially at international
subsidiaries.</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

several alternatives to settle this long-term debt, including the use of cash flows from operating activities, issuance of commercial paper or issuance of other long-term debt.</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

typically expect to settle such interest payments with cash flows from operating activities and/or short-term borrowings.</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD COLSPAN=17 style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-left:10pt;text-indent:-10pt;"><FONT SIZE=2> <SUP>4</SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Refer to Note&nbsp;17 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for information regarding income taxes. As of December&nbsp;31,
 2008, the noncurrent portion of our income tax liability, including accrued interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits, was approximately $447&nbsp;million, which was not included in the total above. At this time, the settlement
period for the noncurrent portion of our income tax liability cannot be determined. In addition, any payments related to unrecognized tax benefits would be partially offset by reductions in payments in other jurisdictions.</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD COLSPAN=17 style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-left:10pt;text-indent:-10pt;"><FONT SIZE=2> <SUP>5</SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT SIZE=2>The purchase obligations include agreements to purchase goods or services that are enforceable and legally binding and that
specify all significant terms, including long-term contractual obligations, open purchase orders, accounts payable and certain accrued liabilities. We expect to fund these obligations with cash flows from operating activities.</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD COLSPAN=17 style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-left:10pt;text-indent:-10pt;"><FONT SIZE=2> <SUP>6</SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT SIZE=2>We expect to fund these marketing obligations with cash flows from operating activities.<BR></FONT>
</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;87, "Employers' Accounting for Pensions," and SFAS No.&nbsp;106, "Employers' Accounting for Postretirement
Benefits Other Than Pensions," as amended by SFAS No.&nbsp;158, "Employers'
Accounting for Defined Benefit Pension and Other Postretirement Plans&#151;an amendment of FASB Statements No.&nbsp;87, 88, 106, and 132(R)," the total accrued benefit liability for pension
and other postretirement benefit plans recognized as of December&nbsp;31, 2008 was approximately $1,620&nbsp;million. Refer to Note&nbsp;16 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. This
amount is impacted by, among other items, pension expense, funding levels, plan amendments, changes in plan demographics and assumptions, investment return on plan assets, and the application of SFAS
No.&nbsp;158. Because the accrued liability does not represent expected liquidity needs, we did not include this amount in the contractual obligations table. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>67</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=69,EFW="2190274",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=360929,FOLIO='67',FILE='DISK121:[09ZAL1.09ZAL74201]DX74201A.;48',USER='HYUNG',CD='26-FEB-2009;00:50' -->
<A NAME="page_dx74201_1_68"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Pension Protection Act of 2006 ("PPA") was enacted in August 2006 and established, among other things, new standards for funding of U.S. defined benefit pension plans. During 2008,
the funded status of the Company's primary U.S. defined benefit pension plan declined as a result of the overall stock market decline. In early 2009, the Company contributed approximately
$175&nbsp;million to this plan. Subsequent to this contribution, the plan is sufficiently funded to maintain maximum flexibility as outlined in the PPA. However, we will consider additional funding
at a later date this year based on asset performance during the beginning of the year. We generally expect to fund all future contributions with cash flows from operating activities. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
international pension plans are funded in accordance with local laws and income tax regulations. We do not expect contributions to these plans to be material in 2009 or thereafter.
Therefore, no amounts have been included in the table above. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;31, 2008, the projected benefit obligation of the U.S. qualified pension plans was $1,918&nbsp;million, and the fair value of plan assets was approximately
$1,442&nbsp;million. The majority of this underfunding was due to the negative impact that the recent credit crisis and financial system instability had on the value of our pension plan assets. As
of December&nbsp;31, 2008, the projected benefit obligation of all pension plans other than the U.S. qualified pension plans was approximately $1,700&nbsp;million, and the fair value of all other
pension plan assets was approximately $848&nbsp;million. The majority of this underfunding is attributable to an international pension plan for certain non-U.S. employees that is
unfunded due to tax law restrictions, as well as our unfunded U.S. nonqualified pension plans. These U.S. nonqualified pension plans provide, for certain associates, benefits that are not permitted to
be funded through a qualified plan because of limits imposed by the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The expected benefit payments for these unfunded pension plans are not included in the table above.
However, we anticipate annual benefit payments to be approximately $40&nbsp;million in 2009 and remain near that level through 2032, decreasing annually thereafter. Refer to Note&nbsp;16 of Notes
to Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Deferred
income tax liabilities as of December&nbsp;31, 2008 were approximately $914&nbsp;million. Refer to Note&nbsp;17 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. This amount
is not included in the total contractual obligations table because we believe this presentation would not be meaningful. Deferred income tax liabilities are calculated based on temporary differences
between the tax bases of assets and liabilities and their respective
book bases, which will result in taxable amounts in future years when the liabilities are settled at their reported financial statement amounts. The results of these calculations do not have a direct
connection with the amount of cash taxes to be paid in any future periods. As a result, scheduling deferred income tax liabilities as payments due by period could be misleading, because this
scheduling would not relate to liquidity needs. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
September&nbsp;3, 2008, we announced our intention to make cash offers to purchase Huiyuan. Assuming full acceptance of the offers, the transaction is valued at approximately
$2.4&nbsp;billion. Refer to the heading "Additional Information." This amount is excluded from the contractual obligations table, because it is subject to preconditions relating to Chinese
regulatory approvals. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;31, 2008, we have recorded approximately $383&nbsp;million in the consolidated balance sheet line item other liabilities for minority interests related to
consolidated entities in which we do not have a 100&nbsp;percent ownership interest. Such minority interests are not liabilities requiring the use of cash or other resources; therefore, this amount
is excluded from the contractual obligations table. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Foreign Exchange  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our international operations are subject to certain opportunities and risks, including currency fluctuations and governmental actions.
We closely monitor our operations in each country and seek to adopt appropriate strategies that are responsive to changing economic and political environments, and to fluctuations in foreign
currencies. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>68</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=70,EFW="2190274",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=858426,FOLIO='68',FILE='DISK121:[09ZAL1.09ZAL74201]DX74201A.;48',USER='HYUNG',CD='26-FEB-2009;00:50' -->
<A NAME="page_dx74201_1_69"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
use 70 functional currencies. Due to our global operations, weakness in some of these currencies might be offset by strength in others. In 2008, 2007 and 2006, the weighted-average
exchange rates for foreign currencies in which the Company conducted operations (all operating currencies), and for certain individual currencies, strengthened (weakened) against the U.S. dollar as
follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><TABLE BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR><!-- TABLE COLUMN WIDTHS SET -->
<TD WIDTH="337" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="12" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="5" ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"></TD>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;These percentages do not include the effects of our hedging activities and, therefore, do not reflect the actual impact of fluctuations in
exchange rates on our operating results. Our foreign currency management program is designed to mitigate, over time, a portion of the impact of exchange rate changes on our net income and earnings per
share. The total currency impact on operating income, including the effect of our hedging activities, was an increase of approximately 6&nbsp;percent in 2008 and an increase of approximately
4&nbsp;percent in 2007. The impact of a stronger U.S. dollar reduced our operating income by approximately 1&nbsp;percent in 2006. Based on the anticipated benefits of hedging coverage in place,
the Company currently expects currencies to have a 10&nbsp;percent to 12&nbsp;percent negative impact on operating income in the first quarter of 2009. The foreign exchange environment is very
volatile, and the Company cannot reasonably estimate the impact of foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations for subsequent periods. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Exchange
gain (loss)&#151;net was a gain of approximately $24&nbsp;million in 2008, and losses of approximately $10&nbsp;million and $15&nbsp;million in 2007 and 2006,
respectively. These amounts were recorded in other income (loss)&#151;net in our consolidated statements of income. Exchange gain (loss)&#151;net includes the remeasurement of monetary
assets and liabilities from certain currencies into functional currencies and the costs of hedging certain exposures of our consolidated balance sheets. Refer to Note&nbsp;11 of Notes to
Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company will continue to manage its foreign currency exposure to mitigate, over time, a portion of the impact of exchange rate changes on net income and earnings per share. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Overview of Financial Position  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our consolidated balance sheet as of December&nbsp;31, 2008, compared to our consolidated balance sheet as of December&nbsp;31,
2007, was impacted by the following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>a decrease in net assets of $2,285&nbsp;million resulting from translation adjustments in various balance sheet
accounts;  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>an increase in cash and cash equivalents of $608&nbsp;million, primarily related to the timing of borrowings; </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>a decrease of $1,637&nbsp;million in our investment in CCE, primarily due to our proportionate share of impairment
charges recorded by CCE;  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>a decrease of $942&nbsp;million in other assets, primarily due to the decline in fair value of pension and other
postretirement benefit plan assets. Prior to this decline in fair value, the plan assets for certain pension and other postretirement benefit plans exceeded the benefit obligation, which resulted in
the recognition of a prepaid asset. The Company has now recognized a liability for these pension and other postretirement benefit plans; </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>69</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
