<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=111,EFW="2190274",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=986946,FOLIO='109',FILE='DISK121:[09ZAL1.09ZAL74201]FT74201A.;48',USER='MSULLIV',CD='26-FEB-2009;11:54' -->
<A NAME="page_ft74201_1_110"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
THE COCA-COLA COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 15: STOCK COMPENSATION PLANS  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective January&nbsp;1, 2006, the Company adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;123(R) using the modified prospective method. Based on the terms of our plans, our Company did not have a cumulative
effect related to its adoption. The adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;123(R) did not have a material impact on our stock-based compensation expense for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. Prior to
2006, our Company accounted for stock option plans and restricted stock plans under the preferable fair value recognition provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;123. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Additionally,
our equity method investees also adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;123(R) effective January&nbsp;1, 2006. Our proportionate share of the stock-based compensation expense resulting
from the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;123(R) by our equity method investees is recognized as a reduction to equity income. The adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;123(R) by our equity method investees did not
have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
total stock-based compensation expense was approximately $266&nbsp;million, $313&nbsp;million and $324&nbsp;million in 2008, 2007 and 2006, respectively. These amounts were
recorded in selling, general and administrative expenses in our consolidated statements of income. The total income tax benefit recognized in the income statement for share-based compensation
arrangements was approximately $72&nbsp;million, $91&nbsp;million and $93&nbsp;million for 2008, 2007 and 2006, respectively. As of December&nbsp;31, 2008, we had approximately
$368&nbsp;million of total unrecognized compensation cost related to nonvested share-based compensation arrangements granted under our plans. This cost is expected to be recognized over a
weighted-average period of 1.7&nbsp;years as stock-based compensation expense. This expected cost does not include the impact of any future stock-based compensation awards. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Stock Option Plans  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under our 1991 Stock Option Plan (the "1991 Option Plan"), a maximum of 120&nbsp;million shares of our common stock was approved to
be issued or transferred, through the grant of stock options, to certain officers and employees. Options to purchase common stock under the 1991 Option Plan have been granted to Company employees at
fair market value at the date of grant. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
1999 Stock Option Plan (the "1999 Option Plan") was approved by shareowners in April 1999. Under the 1999 Option Plan, a maximum of 120&nbsp;million shares of our common stock was
approved to be issued or transferred, through the grant of stock options, to certain officers and employees. Options to purchase common stock under the 1999 Option Plan have been granted to Company
employees at fair market value at the date of grant. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
2002 Stock Option Plan (the "2002 Option Plan") was approved by shareowners in April 2002. An amendment to the 2002 Option Plan which permitted the issuance of stock appreciation
rights was approved by shareowners in April 2003. Under the 2002 Option Plan, a maximum of 120&nbsp;million shares of our common stock was approved to be issued or transferred, through the grant of
stock options or stock appreciation rights, to certain officers and employees. No stock appreciation rights have been issued under the 2002 Option Plan as of December&nbsp;31, 2008. Options to
purchase common stock under the 2002 Option Plan have been granted to Company employees at fair market value at the date of grant. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
2008 Stock Option Plan (the "2008 Option Plan") was approved by shareowners in April 2008. Under the 2008 Option Plan, a maximum of 140&nbsp;million shares of our common stock was
approved to be issued or transferred to certain officers and employees pursuant to stock options granted under the 2008 Option Plan. Options to purchase common stock under the 2008 Option Plan have
been generally granted to Company employees at fair market value at the date of grant. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>110</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=112,EFW="2190274",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=1011271,FOLIO='110',FILE='DISK121:[09ZAL1.09ZAL74201]FT74201A.;48',USER='MSULLIV',CD='26-FEB-2009;11:54' -->
<A NAME="page_ft74201_1_111"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
THE COCA-COLA COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 15: STOCK COMPENSATION PLANS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Stock
options granted in December 2003 and thereafter generally become exercisable over four years (with approximately 25&nbsp;percent of the total grant vesting each year on the
anniversary of the grant date) and expire 10&nbsp;years from the date of grant. Stock options granted from 1999 through July 2003 generally became exercisable over four years and expire
15&nbsp;years from the date of grant. Prior to 1999, stock options generally became exercisable over a three-year vesting period and expire 10&nbsp;years from the date of grant. The
1999 Stock Option Plan and the 2002 Stock Option Plan have been amended to provide a maximum option term of 10&nbsp;years for all grants in 2008 and beyond. The 2008 Option Plan provides a maximum
option term of 10&nbsp;years. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
fair value of each option award is estimated on the grant date using a Black-Scholes-Merton option-pricing model that uses the assumptions noted in the following table. The expected
term of the options represents the period of time that options granted are expected to be outstanding and is derived by analyzing historic exercise behavior. Expected volatilities are based on implied
volatilities from traded options on the Company's stock, historical volatility of the Company's stock, and other factors. The risk-free interest rate for the period matching the expected
term of the option is based on the U.S. Treasury yield curve in effect at the time of the grant. The dividend yield is the calculated yield on the Company's stock at the time of the grant. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
shares of common stock to be issued, transferred and/or sold under the stock option plans are made available from authorized and unissued Company common stock or from the Company's
treasury shares. In 2007, the Company began issuing common stock under these plans from the Company's treasury shares. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table sets forth information about the weighted-average fair value of options granted during the past three years and the weighted-average assumptions used for such grants: </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 15: STOCK COMPENSATION PLANS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A summary of stock option activity under all plans for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008, 2007 and 2006 is as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- TABLE COLUMN WIDTHS END --></TR>

<TR VALIGN="TOP">

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="fv74201_the_coca-cola_company_and_subs__the03212"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_fv74201_1"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>  THE COCA-COLA COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES    <BR>    <BR>    NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 15: STOCK COMPENSATION PLANS (Continued)  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Restricted Stock Award Plans  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under the amended 1989 Restricted Stock Award Plan and the amended 1983 Restricted Stock Award Plan (the "Restricted Stock Award
Plans"), 40&nbsp;million and 24&nbsp;million shares of restricted common stock, respectively, were originally available to be granted to certain officers and key employees of our Company. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2008, approximately 25&nbsp;million shares remain available for grant under the Restricted Stock Award Plans, when all outstanding awards including promises to grant restricted
stock and performance share units at the target level are included. For time-based and performance-based restricted stock awards, participants are entitled to vote and receive dividends on
the restricted shares. For performance share units, participants generally only receive dividends or dividend equivalents once the performance criteria has been certified and the restricted stock or
promises to grant restricted stock have been issued. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
awards prior to January&nbsp;1, 2008 under the 1983 Restricted Stock Award Plan, participants are reimbursed by our Company for income taxes imposed on the award, but not for taxes
generated by the reimbursement payment. The Company has not granted awards from the 1983 Restricted Stock Plan since 1993. The 1983 Restricted Stock Plan has been amended to eliminate this tax
reimbursement for awards after January&nbsp;1, 2008. The shares are subject to certain transfer restrictions and may be forfeited if a participant leaves our Company for reasons other than
retirement, disability or death, absent a change in control of our Company. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following awards were outstanding and nonvested as of December&nbsp;31, 2008: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>474,478 shares of time-based restricted stock and promises to grant restricted stock in which the restrictions
lapse upon the achievement of continued employment over a specified period of time;  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>298,009 shares of performance-based restricted stock and promises to grant restricted stock in which restrictions lapse
upon the achievement of specific performance goals over a specified performance period;  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>4,533,736 performance share units which could result in a future grant of restricted stock after the achievement of
specific performance goals over a specified performance period. Such awards are subject to adjustment based on the final performance relative to the goals, resulting in a minimum grant of no shares
and a maximum grant of 7,011,354 shares; and  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>709,808 shares of restricted stock and promises to grant restricted stock from conversion of performance share units. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company recognizes compensation expense for awards that are subject to performance criteria, when it is probable that the performance criteria specified in the plan will be achieved.
The compensation expense is recognized on a straight-line basis over the remaining vesting period and is recorded in selling, general and administrative expenses. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>113</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Performance-Based Restricted Stock Awards  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2001, shareowners approved an amendment to the 1989 Restricted Stock Award Plan to allow for the grant of performance-based awards.
These awards are released only upon the achievement of specific measurable performance criteria. These awards pay dividends during the performance period. The majority of awards have specific
performance targets for achievement. If the performance targets are not met, the awards will be cancelled. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>114</FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Performance Share Unit Awards  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2003, the Company established a program to grant performance share units under the 1989 Restricted Stock Award Plan to executives.
In 2008, the Company expanded the program to award a mix of stock options and performance share units to eligible employees in addition to executives. The number of shares earned is determined at the
end of each performance period, generally three years, based on the actual performance criteria predetermined by the Board of Directors at the time of grant. If the performance criteria are met, the
award results in a grant of restricted stock or promises to grant restricted stock, which are then generally subject to a holding period in order for the restricted stock to be released. For
performance share units granted before 2008, this holding period is generally two years. For
performance share units granted in 2008, this holding period is generally one year. Restrictions on such stock generally lapse at the end of the holding period. Performance share units generally do
not pay dividends or allow voting rights during the performance period. Accordingly, the fair value of these units is the quoted market value of the Company stock on the date of the grant less the
present value of the expected dividends not received during the performance period. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Performance
share units require achievement of certain financial measures, primarily compound annual growth in earnings per share or economic profit. These financial measures are
adjusted for certain items approved and certified by the Audit Committee of the Board of Directors. The purpose of these adjustments is to ensure a consistent year to year comparison of the specific
performance criteria. Economic profit is our net operating profit after tax less the cost of the capital used in our business. In the event that the financial result equals the predefined target, the
Company will grant the number of restricted shares equal to the Target Award in the underlying performance share units agreement. In the event the financial result exceeds the predefined target,
additional shares up to the Maximum Award may be granted. In the event the financial result falls below the predefined target, a reduced number of shares may be granted. If the financial result falls
below the Threshold Award performance level, no shares will be granted. Performance share units are generally settled in </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>115</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=117,EFW="2190274",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=20001,FOLIO='115',FILE='DISK121:[09ZAL1.09ZAL74201]FV74201A.;34',USER='MSULLIV',CD='26-FEB-2009;11:54' -->
<A NAME="page_fv74201_1_116"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
THE COCA-COLA COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 15: STOCK COMPENSATION PLANS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>stock,
except for certain circumstances such as death or disability, where former employees or their beneficiaries are provided a cash equivalent payment. Of the outstanding granted performance share
units as of December&nbsp;31, 2008, 710,700; 985,168; and 2,667,168 awards are for the 2006-2008, 2007-2009 and 2008-2010 performance periods, respectively. Also,
outstanding as of December&nbsp;31, 2008, are 98,700 performance share units granted in 2007 with certain financial measures of a business unit of the Company as the performance criteria. In
addition, 72,000 performance share units, with predefined qualitative performance criteria and release criteria that differ from the program described above, were granted in 2004 and were outstanding
as of December&nbsp;31, 2008. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table summarizes information about performance share units based on the Target Award amounts in the performance share unit agreements: </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 16: PENSION AND OTHER POSTRETIREMENT BENEFIT PLANS  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Company sponsors and/or contributes to pension and postretirement health care and life insurance benefit plans covering substantially all U.S. employees. We also sponsor
nonqualified, unfunded defined benefit pension plans for certain associates. In addition, our Company and its subsidiaries have various pension plans and other forms of postretirement arrangements
outside the United States. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective
December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;158, which required the recognition in pension obligations and AOCI of actuarial gains or losses, prior service
costs or credits and transition assets or obligations that had previously been deferred under the reporting requirements of SFAS No.&nbsp;87, SFAS No.&nbsp;106 and SFAS No.&nbsp;132(R). As a
result of the adoption, the Company recorded approximately $288&nbsp;million as an adjustment to AOCI as of December&nbsp;31, 2006. The applicable December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007 balances
included in our consolidated financial statements and footnotes reflect the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;158. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>117</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=119,EFW="2190274",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=216288,FOLIO='117',FILE='DISK121:[09ZAL1.09ZAL74201]FV74201A.;34',USER='MSULLIV',CD='26-FEB-2009;11:54' -->
<A NAME="page_fv74201_1_118"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
THE COCA-COLA COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 16: PENSION AND OTHER POSTRETIREMENT BENEFIT PLANS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
February and October of 2007, the Company amended its U.S. retiree medical plan to limit the Company's exposure to increases in retiree medical costs associated with current and
future retirees. Based on the materiality of the change in liability resulting from the amendments, we remeasured the assets and liabilities of the U.S. retiree medical plan effective
February&nbsp;28, 2007 and October&nbsp;31, 2007. As a result of the remeasurements, the Company reduced its liabilities for the U.S. retiree medical plan by approximately $435&nbsp;million. In
accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;158, the Company also recognized the appropriate effects of the change in AOCI and deferred taxes. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
primary U.S. defined benefit pension plan was amended effective December&nbsp;31, 2008. The plan will now have a two-part formula to determine pension benefits. The
first part will retain the current
final-average pay structure, where service will freeze as of January&nbsp;1, 2010, with pay escalating for the lesser of 10&nbsp;years or until termination. The second part of the formula will be
a cash balance account which will commence January&nbsp;1, 2010 under which employees will receive credits based on age, service, pay and interest. The plan was also modified to allow lump sum
distributions. These changes, as well as related changes to other U.S. plans, reduced pension obligations by approximately $21&nbsp;million. In addition, the U.S. retiree medical plan was amended to
close the plan to new hires effective January&nbsp;1, 2009. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain
amounts in the prior years' disclosure have been reclassified to conform to the current year presentation. </FONT></P>

<UL>

</UL>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="fx74201_the_coca-cola_company_and_subs__the03212"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_fx74201_1"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>  THE COCA-COLA COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES    <BR>    <BR>    NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 16: PENSION AND OTHER POSTRETIREMENT BENEFIT PLANS (Continued)  </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The accumulated benefit obligation for our pension plans was approximately $3,209&nbsp;million and approximately $3,080&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007,
respectively. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
pension plans with projected benefit obligations in excess of plan assets, the total projected benefit obligation and fair value of plan assets were approximately
$3,416&nbsp;million and $2,051&nbsp;million, respectively, as of December&nbsp;31, 2008, and $1,372&nbsp;million and $691&nbsp;million, respectively, as of December&nbsp;31, 2007. For
pension plans with accumulated benefit obligations in excess of plan assets, the total accumulated benefit obligation and fair value of plan assets were approximately $2,881&nbsp;million and
$1,885&nbsp;million, respectively, as of December&nbsp;31, 2008, and approximately $996&nbsp;million and $441&nbsp;million, respectively, as of December&nbsp;31, 2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table sets forth the change in the fair value of plan assets for our benefit plans (in millions): </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
THE COCA-COLA COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 16: PENSION AND OTHER POSTRETIREMENT BENEFIT PLANS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table sets forth the changes in AOCI for our benefit plans (in millions, pretax): </FONT></P>

<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><TABLE BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>

<TD style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-left:11pt;text-indent:-11pt;"><FONT SIZE=2> </FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=5 ALIGN="CENTER" VALIGN="BOTTOM" style="font-family:times;border-bottom:solid #000000 1.0pt;"><FONT SIZE=1>Pension Benefits </FONT>&nbsp;</TD>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Assumptions  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain weighted-average assumptions used in computing the benefit obligations are as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TABLEWIDTH,"88%" -->

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><TABLE width="88%"  BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR><!-- TABLE COLUMN WIDTHS SET -->
<TD WIDTH="275" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="12" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="5" ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="12" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="30" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="5" ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="12" style="font-family:times;"></TD>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_fz74201_1_122"> </A>


<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"Black" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"font-family:times;" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TABLESHADECOLOR,"#CCEEFF" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_STABLERULES,"border-bottom:solid #000000 1.0pt;" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DTABLERULES,"border-bottom:solid #000000 2.25pt;" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_SCRTABLERULES,"border-bottom:solid #000000 1.0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;" -->





<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DCRTABLERULES,"border-bottom:solid #000000 2.25pt;margin-bottom:0pt;" -->


<!-- PARA=JUSTIFY -->
</FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="fz74201_the_coca-cola_company_and_subs__the03212"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_fz74201_1"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>  THE COCA-COLA COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES    <BR>    <BR>    NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 16: PENSION AND OTHER POSTRETIREMENT BENEFIT PLANS (Continued)  </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2007, the Company amended its U.S. retiree medical plan to limit the Company's exposure to increases in retiree medical costs for both current and future retirees. As a result,
the effects of a one percentage point change in the assumed health care cost trend rate would not be significant to the Company. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
discount rate assumptions used to account for pension and other postretirement benefit plans reflect the rates at which the benefit obligations could be effectively settled. Rates
for each of our U.S. plans at December&nbsp;31, 2008 were determined using a cash flow matching technique whereby the rates of a yield curve, developed from high-quality debt securities,
were applied to the benefit obligations to determine the appropriate discount rate. For our non-U.S. plans, we base the discount rate on comparable indices within each of those countries.
The rate of compensation increase assumption is determined by the Company based upon annual reviews. We review external data and our own historical trends for health care costs to determine the health
care cost trend rate assumptions. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Plan Assets  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Pension Benefit Plans  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table sets forth the actual asset allocation and weighted-average target asset allocation for our U.S. and
non-U.S. pension plan assets: </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investment objectives for the Company's U.S. pension plan assets, which comprise 66&nbsp;percent of total pension plan assets as of
December&nbsp;31, 2008, are to: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>optimize
the long-term return on plan assets at an acceptable level of risk;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>maintain
a broad diversification across asset classes and among investment managers;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(3)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>maintain
careful control of the risk level within each asset class; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(4)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>focus
on a long-term return objective. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Asset
allocation targets promote optimal expected return and volatility characteristics given the long-term time horizon for fulfilling the obligations of the pension plans.
Selection of the targeted asset allocation for U.S. plan assets was based upon a review of the expected return and risk characteristics of each asset class, as well as the correlation of returns among
asset classes. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>122</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=124,EFW="2190274",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=840006,FOLIO='122',FILE='DISK121:[09ZAL1.09ZAL74201]FZ74201A.;70',USER='MSULLIV',CD='26-FEB-2009;11:54' -->
<A NAME="page_fz74201_1_123"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
THE COCA-COLA COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 16: PENSION AND OTHER POSTRETIREMENT BENEFIT PLANS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investment
guidelines are established with each investment manager. These guidelines provide the parameters within which the investment managers agree to operate, including criteria that
determine eligible and ineligible securities, diversification requirements and credit quality standards, where applicable. Unless exceptions have been approved, investment managers are prohibited from
buying or selling commodities, futures or option contracts, as well as from short selling of securities. Furthermore, investment managers agree to obtain written approval for deviations from stated
investment style or guidelines. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;31, 2008, no investment manager was responsible for more than 10&nbsp;percent of total U.S. plan assets. In addition, diversification requirements for each
investment manager prevent a single security or other investment from exceeding 10&nbsp;percent, at historical cost, of the individual manager's portfolio. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
expected long-term rate of return assumption for U.S. plan assets is based upon the target asset allocation and is determined using forward-looking assumptions in the
context of historical
returns and volatilities for each asset class, as well as correlations among asset classes. We evaluate the rate of return assumption on an annual basis. The expected long-term rate of
return assumption used in computing 2008 net periodic pension cost for the U.S. plans was 8.5&nbsp;percent. As of December&nbsp;31, 2008, the 10-year annualized return on U.S. plan
assets was 3.0&nbsp;percent, the 15-year annualized return was 7.5&nbsp;percent, and the annualized return since inception was 10.7&nbsp;percent. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Plan
assets for our pension plans outside the United States are insignificant on an individual plan basis. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Other Benefit Plans  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Plan assets associated with other benefits represent funding of the primary U.S. postretirement benefit plan. In late 2006, we
established and contributed $216&nbsp;million to a U.S. Voluntary Employee Beneficiary Association ("VEBA"), a tax-qualified trust. While the VEBA assets will remain segregated from the
primary U.S. pension master trust, the current investments were determined in a methodology similar to that applied to the U.S. pension plans described above. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>123</FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Defined Contribution Plans  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Company sponsors qualified defined contribution plans covering substantially all U.S. employees. Under the primary plan, we match
100&nbsp;percent of participants' contributions up to a maximum of 3&nbsp;percent of compensation. Company costs related to the U.S. plans were approximately $22&nbsp;million, $29&nbsp;million
and $25&nbsp;million in 2008, 2007 and 2006, respectively. We also sponsor defined contribution plans in certain locations outside the United States. Company costs associated with those plans were
approximately $20&nbsp;million, $25&nbsp;million and $16&nbsp;million in 2008, 2007 and 2006, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>124</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=126,EFW="2190274",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=118080,FOLIO='124',FILE='DISK121:[09ZAL1.09ZAL74201]FZ74201A.;70',USER='MSULLIV',CD='26-FEB-2009;11:54' -->
<A NAME="page_fz74201_1_125"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We made income tax payments of approximately $1,942&nbsp;million, $1,596&nbsp;million and $1,601&nbsp;million in 2008, 2007 and 2006,
respectively. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
THE COCA-COLA COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 17: INCOME TAXES (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A
reconciliation of the statutory U.S. federal tax rate and effective tax rates is as follows: </FONT></P>

<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><TABLE width="60%"  BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>

<!-- TABLE COLUMN WIDTHS END --></TR>

<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-left:11pt;text-indent:-11pt;"><FONT SIZE=2> </FONT><FONT SIZE=1>Year Ended December&nbsp;31,</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B>2008</B></FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1> 2007</FONT></TD>

<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=128,EFW="2190274",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=315554,FOLIO='126',FILE='DISK121:[09ZAL1.09ZAL74201]FZ74201A.;70',USER='MSULLIV',CD='26-FEB-2009;11:54' -->
<A NAME="page_fz74201_1_127"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
THE COCA-COLA COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 17: INCOME TAXES (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our effective tax rate reflects the tax benefits from having significant operations outside the United States that are taxed at rates lower than
the statutory U.S. rate of 35&nbsp;percent. During 2008, 2007 and 2006, the Company had several subsidiaries that benefited from various tax incentive grants. The terms of these grants range from
2010 to 2031. The Company expects each of the grants to be renewed indefinitely. The grants did not have a material effect on the results of operations for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008,
2007 or 2006. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company or one of its subsidiaries files income tax returns in the U.S. federal jurisdiction and various states and foreign jurisdictions. U.S. tax authorities have completed their
federal income tax examinations for all years prior to 2005. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;With
respect to state and local jurisdictions and countries outside the United States, with limited exceptions, the Company and its subsidiaries are no longer subject to income tax
audits for years before 2001. Although the outcome of tax audits is always uncertain, the Company believes that adequate amounts of tax, including interest and penalties, have been provided for any
adjustments that are expected to result from those years. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company adopted the provisions of Interpretation No.&nbsp;48, effective January&nbsp;1, 2007. As a result of the implementation of Interpretation No.&nbsp;48, the Company
recorded an approximate $65&nbsp;million increase in liabilities for unrecognized tax benefits, which was accounted for as a reduction to the January&nbsp;1, 2007, balance of reinvested earnings.
As of December&nbsp;31, 2008, the gross amount of unrecognized tax benefits was approximately $369&nbsp;million. If the Company were to prevail on all uncertain tax positions, the net effect would
be a benefit to the Company's effective tax rate of approximately $174&nbsp;million, exclusive of any benefits related to interest and penalties. The remaining approximately $195&nbsp;million,
which was recorded as a deferred tax asset, primarily represents tax benefits that would be received in different tax jurisdictions in the event that the Company did not prevail on all uncertain tax
positions. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
early July 2008, agreements were reached between the U.S. government and a foreign government concerning the allocation of income between the two tax jurisdictions. Pursuant to these
agreements, we made cash payments during the third quarter of 2008 that constituted payments of tax and interest. These payments were partially offset by tax credits taken in the third quarter and
fourth quarter of 2008, and tax refunds and interest on refunds to be received in 2009. These benefits had been recorded as deferred tax assets in prior periods. As a result of these agreements, these
deferred tax assets have been reclassified to income tax and interest receivables. The settlements did not have a material impact on the Company's consolidated statement of income for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2008. The impact of these agreements, and other 2008 activity, is reflected in the balances of our unrecognized tax benefits and deferred tax assets as of December&nbsp;31, 2008,
which is further described below. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>127</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

reconciliation of the changes in the gross balance of unrecognized tax benefits amounts is as follows (in millions): </FONT></P>

</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company recognizes accrued interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits in income tax expense. As of December&nbsp;31, 2008,
the Company had approximately $110&nbsp;million in interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits accrued, of which approximately $14&nbsp;million of benefit was recognized through
tax expense in 2008. If the Company were to prevail on all uncertain tax positions, the reversal of this accrual would also be a benefit to the Company's effective tax rate. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;31, 2007, the Company had approximately $272&nbsp;million in interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits accrued, of which approximately
$82&nbsp;million was recognized through tax expense in 2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;It
is expected that the amount of unrecognized tax benefits will change in the next twelve months; however, we do not expect the change to have a significant impact on our consolidated
statement of income or consolidated balance sheet. These changes may be the result of settlement of ongoing audits, statute of limitations expiring, or final settlements in transfer pricing matters
that are the subject of litigation. At this time, an estimate of the range of the reasonably possible outcomes cannot be made. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>128</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<!-- TOC_END -->
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="gc74201_the_coca-cola_company_and_subs__the03212"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_gc74201_1"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>  THE COCA-COLA COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES    <BR>    <BR>    NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 17: INCOME TAXES (Continued)  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Undistributed earnings of the Company's foreign subsidiaries amounted to approximately $14.1&nbsp;billion as of December&nbsp;31, 2008. Those earnings are considered to be
indefinitely reinvested and, accordingly, no U.S. federal and state income taxes have been provided thereon. Upon distribution of those earnings in the form of dividends or otherwise, the Company
would be subject to both U.S. income taxes (subject to an adjustment for foreign tax credits) and withholding taxes payable to the various foreign countries. Determination of the amount of
unrecognized deferred U.S. income tax liability is not practical because of the complexities associated with its hypothetical calculation; however, unrecognized foreign tax credits would be available
to reduce a portion of the U.S. tax liability. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
tax effects of temporary differences and carryforwards that give rise to deferred tax assets and liabilities consist of the following (in millions): </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
THE COCA-COLA COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 17: INCOME TAXES (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007, we had approximately $454&nbsp;million and $610&nbsp;million, respectively, of net deferred tax
liabilities located in countries outside the United States. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;31, 2008, we had approximately $2,496&nbsp;million of loss carryforwards available to reduce future taxable income. Loss carryforwards of approximately
$230&nbsp;million must be utilized within the next five years, $21&nbsp;million must be utilized within the next 10&nbsp;years, and the remainder can be utilized over a period greater than
10&nbsp;years. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;An
analysis of our deferred tax asset valuation allowances is as follows (in millions): </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's deferred tax asset valuation allowances are primarily the result of uncertainties regarding the future realization of recorded tax
benefits on tax loss carryforwards from operations in various jurisdictions. In 2008, the Company recognized a decrease in its valuation allowances of $42&nbsp;million, primarily related to the
utilization of capital loss carryforwards used to offset taxable gains on the sale of our investment in Remil. In addition, the Company also recognized a decrease to the valuation allowance as a
result of asset write-offs, pension adjustments and the impact of foreign currency fluctuations in 2008. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2007, the Company recognized a net decrease in its valuation allowances of $67&nbsp;million. This decrease was primarily related to the reversal of valuation allowances on deferred
tax assets recorded on the basis difference in equity investments. The Company also recognized a decrease in certain deferred tax assets and corresponding valuation allowances related to a change in
German tax rates. In 2006, the Company recognized a net decrease in its valuation allowances of $108&nbsp;million. This decrease was primarily related to the reversal of valuation allowances that
covered certain deferred tax assets recorded on capital loss carryforwards. A portion of the capital loss carryforwards was utilized to offset taxable gains on the sale of a portion of the investments
in Coca-Cola Icecek and Coca-Cola FEMSA. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 18: RESTRUCTURING COSTS  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Streamlining Initiatives  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2007, the Company took steps to streamline and simplify its operations globally. In North America, the Company reorganized its
operations around three main business units: Sparkling Beverages, Still Beverages and Emerging Brands. In Ireland, the Company announced a plan to close its beverage concentrate manufacturing and
distribution plant in Drogheda, which was closed during the third quarter of 2008. The plant closure is expected to improve operating productivity and enhance capacity utilization. The costs
associated with this plant closure are included in the Corporate operating segment. Selected other operations also took steps to streamline their operations to improve overall efficiency and
effectiveness. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Employees
separated or to be separated from the Company as a result of these streamlining initiatives were offered severance or early retirement packages, as appropriate, that included
both financial and nonfinancial components. The expenses recorded during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007 included costs related </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>130</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 18: RESTRUCTURING COSTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>to
involuntary terminations and other direct costs associated with implementing these initiatives. Other direct costs included expenses to relocate employees; contract termination costs; costs
associated with the development, communication and administration of these initiatives; accelerated depreciation; and asset write-offs. The Company has incurred total pretax expenses of
approximately $410&nbsp;million related to these streamlining initiatives since they commenced in 2007, which were recorded in the line item other operating charges in our consolidated statements of
income. The Company does not anticipate significant additional charges, individually or in the aggregate, related to these initiatives. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Other Restructuring Activities  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2008, the Company incurred approximately $21&nbsp;million of charges related to other restructuring activities outside the
scope of the aforementioned streamlining initiatives, which primarily related to the integration of the 18 German bottling and distribution operations acquired in 2007. These charges were recorded in
the line item other operating charges in our consolidated statement of income, and impacted the Bottling Investments operating segment. This portion of the integration costs did not qualify to be
accrued during purchase accounting. Refer to Note&nbsp;20. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>131</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=133,EFW="2190274",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=306621,FOLIO='131',FILE='DISK121:[09ZAL1.09ZAL74201]GC74201A.;41',USER='MSULLIV',CD='26-FEB-2009;11:54' -->
<A NAME="page_gc74201_1_132"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
THE COCA-COLA COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 18: RESTRUCTURING COSTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Productivity Initiatives  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2008, the Company announced a transformation effort centered on productivity initiatives that will provide additional
flexibility to invest for growth. The initiatives are expected to impact a number of areas, and include aggressively managing operating expenses supported by lean techniques; redesigning key processes
to drive standardization and effectiveness; better leveraging our size and scale; and driving savings in indirect costs through the implementation of a "procure-to-pay"
program. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company has incurred total pretax expenses of approximately $55&nbsp;million related to these productivity initiatives since they commenced in the first quarter of 2008, which were
recorded in the line item other operating charges in our consolidated statement of income and impacted the Corporate operating segment. Other direct costs included both internal and external costs
associated with the development, communication, administration and implementation of these initiatives. The Company currently expects the total cost of these initiatives to be approximately
$500&nbsp;million and anticipates recognizing the remainder of the costs by the end of 2011. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table summarizes the balance of accrued expenses related to productivity initiatives and the changes in the accrued amounts for the applicable periods (in millions): </FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 19: SIGNIFICANT OPERATING AND NONOPERATING ITEMS  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2008, we recorded our proportionate share of approximately $7.6&nbsp;billion pretax ($4.9&nbsp;billion after-tax) of charges recorded by CCE due to impairments of its
North American franchise rights. The Company's proportionate share of these charges was approximately $1.6&nbsp;billion. In addition to these charges, our Company also recorded charges of
approximately $30&nbsp;million, primarily related to our proportionate share of restructuring costs recorded by CCE. Our Company's proportionate share of CCE's asset impairment charges and
restructuring costs were recorded to equity income (loss)&#151;net in our consolidated statement of income and impacted the Bottling Investments operating segment. Refer to Note&nbsp;3. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition to our proportionate share of charges recorded by CCE discussed above, the Company recognized a net charge of approximately $30&nbsp;million to equity income
(loss)&#151;net in our consolidated statement of income in 2008, primarily related to our proportionate share of restructuring charges recorded by our equity method investees. None of these
items was individually significant. These charges impacted the Europe, North America and Bottling Investments operating segments. Refer to Note&nbsp;3. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2008, the Company incurred other operating charges of approximately $350&nbsp;million, which consisted of approximately $194&nbsp;million related to restructuring charges,
$63&nbsp;million due to contract termination fees, $55&nbsp;million attributable to productivity initiatives and $38&nbsp;million as a result of asset impairments. Refer to Note&nbsp;18 for
additional information related to the restructuring charges and productivity initiatives. The contract </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>132</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_gc74201_1_133"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
THE COCA-COLA COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 19: SIGNIFICANT OPERATING AND NONOPERATING ITEMS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>termination
costs were primarily related to penalties incurred by the Company to terminate existing supply and co-packer agreements. Charges related to asset impairments were primarily due
to the write-down of manufacturing lines that produce product packaging materials. These charges impacted the Eurasia and Africa, Latin America, North America, Bottling Investments and
Corporate operating segments. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2008, the Company recorded charges of approximately $84&nbsp;million to other income (loss)&#151;net, which primarily consisted of $81&nbsp;million of
other-than-temporary impairment charges. As of December&nbsp;31, 2008, the Company had several investments classified as available-for-sale securities
in which our cost basis exceeded the&nbsp;fair value of the investment, each of which initially occurred between the end of the second quarter and the beginning of the third quarter of 2008.
Management assessed each individual investment to determine if the&nbsp;decline in fair value was other than temporary. Based on these assessments, management determined that the decline in fair
value of each investment was other than temporary. These impairment charges impacted the North America, Bottling Investments and Corporate operating segments. Refer to Note&nbsp;10. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2008, the Company recognized gains of approximately $119&nbsp;million due to divestitures, primarily related to the sale of Remil to Coca-Cola FEMSA and the sale of
49&nbsp;percent of our interest in Coca-Cola Pakistan to Coca-Cola Icecek. These gains impacted the Bottling Investments and Corporate operating segments and are included in
other income (loss)&#151;net in our consolidated statement of income. Refer to Note&nbsp;3. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2007, our Company recorded restructuring charges of approximately $237&nbsp;million and asset write-downs totaling approximately $31&nbsp;million related to certain assets and
investments in bottling operations, none of which was individually significant. Of this total, approximately $14&nbsp;million was recorded in cost of goods sold, and approximately
$254&nbsp;million was recorded in other operating charges in our consolidated statement of income. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2007, the Company sold a portion of its interest in Coca-Cola Amatil for proceeds of approximately $143&nbsp;million. As a result of this transaction, we recognized a
pretax gain of approximately $73&nbsp;million, which impacted the Corporate operating segment and was included in other income (loss)&#151;net in our consolidated statement of income. Refer
to Note&nbsp;3. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2007, the Company sold substantially all of its interest in Vonpar. Total proceeds from the sale were approximately $238&nbsp;million, and we recognized a pretax gain on this
sale of approximately $70&nbsp;million, which impacted the Corporate operating segment and was included in other income (loss)&#151;net in our consolidated statement of income. Refer to
Note&nbsp;3. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2007, the Company recorded pretax gains of approximately $66&nbsp;million and $18&nbsp;million resulting from the sales of real estate in Spain and the United States,
respectively. The gains were included in other income (loss)&#151;net in the consolidated statement of income and impacted the Corporate operating segment. Total proceeds amounted to
approximately $106&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Equity
income in 2007 was reduced by approximately $99&nbsp;million in the Bottling Investments operating segment related to our proportionate share of asset write-downs recorded by
CCBPI. The asset write-downs primarily related to excess and obsolete bottles and cases at CCBPI. Refer to Note&nbsp;3. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2007, our equity income was also reduced by approximately $62&nbsp;million in the Bottling Investments operating segment related to our proportionate share of an impairment recorded
by Coca-Cola Amatil as a result of the sale of its bottling operations in South Korea. Refer to Note&nbsp;3. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
THE COCA-COLA COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 19: SIGNIFICANT OPERATING AND NONOPERATING ITEMS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Equity
income was increased in 2007 by approximately $11&nbsp;million in the Bottling Investments operating segment, primarily consisting of our proportionate share of tax benefits
recorded by CCE, partially offset by our proportionate share of restructuring charges recorded by CCE. Refer to Note&nbsp;3. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2006, our Company recorded charges of approximately $606&nbsp;million related to our proportionate share of charges recorded by our equity method investees. Of this amount,
approximately $602&nbsp;million related to our proportionate share of an impairment charge recorded by CCE for its North American franchise rights. Our proportionate share of CCE's charges also
included approximately $18&nbsp;million due to restructuring charges recorded by CCE. These charges were partially offset by approximately $33&nbsp;million related to our proportionate share of
changes in certain of CCE's state and Canadian federal and provincial tax rates. The charges were recorded in the line item equity income (loss)&#151;net in the consolidated statement of
income. All of these charges and changes impacted our Bottling Investments operating segment. Refer to Note&nbsp;3. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2006, our Company also recorded charges of approximately $112&nbsp;million, primarily related to the impairment of assets and investments in our bottling operations,
approximately $53&nbsp;million for contract termination costs related to production capacity efficiencies and approximately $24&nbsp;million related to other restructuring costs. These charges
impacted the Eurasia and Africa, Europe, Pacific, Bottling Investments and Corporate operating segments. None of these charges was individually significant. Approximately $4&nbsp;million of these
charges was recorded in the line item cost of goods sold and approximately $185&nbsp;million of these charges was recorded in the line item other operating charges in the consolidated statement of
income. Refer to Note&nbsp;21 for the impact on our operating segments. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company made a $100&nbsp;million donation to The Coca-Cola Foundation in 2006, which resulted in a charge to the consolidated statement of income line item selling,
general and administrative expenses and impacted the Corporate operating segment. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2006, the Company sold a portion of its Coca-Cola FEMSA shares to FEMSA and recorded a pretax gain of approximately $175&nbsp;million in the consolidated statement of
income line item other income (loss)&#151;net, which impacted the Corporate operating segment. Refer to Note&nbsp;3. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company sold a portion of our investment in Coca-Cola Icecek in an initial public offering in 2006. Our Company received net cash proceeds of approximately
$198&nbsp;million and realized a pretax gain of approximately $123&nbsp;million, which was recorded as other income (loss)&#151;net in the consolidated statement of income and impacted the
Corporate operating segment. Refer to Note&nbsp;3. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 20: ACQUISITIONS AND INVESTMENTS  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On September&nbsp;3, 2008, we announced our intention to make cash offers to purchase Huiyuan. The making of the offers is subject to preconditions relating to Chinese regulatory
approvals. Refer to Note&nbsp;13. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2008, our Company's acquisition and investment activities totaled approximately $759&nbsp;million, primarily related to the purchase of trademarks, brands and licenses. Included
in these investment activities was the acquisition of brands and licenses in Denmark and Finland from Carlsberg Group Beverages ("Carlsberg") for approximately $225&nbsp;million. None of the other
acquisitions or investments was individually significant. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2007, our Company's acquisition and investment activity, including the acquisition of trademarks, totaled approximately $5,653&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>
