<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ge74201_the_coca-cola_company_and_subs__the03212"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ge74201_1"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>  THE COCA-COLA COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES    <BR>    <BR>    NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 20: ACQUISITIONS AND INVESTMENTS (Continued)  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the fourth quarter of 2007, the Company and Coca-Cola FEMSA jointly acquired Jugos del Valle, the second largest producer of packaged juices, nectars and fruit-flavored
beverages in Mexico and the largest producer of such beverages in Brazil. The purchase price was approximately $370&nbsp;million plus the assumption of approximately $85&nbsp;million in debt and
was split equally between the Company and Coca-Cola FEMSA. As of December&nbsp;31, 2008, the Company owned a 50&nbsp;percent interest in Jugos del Valle. The Company's investment in
Jugos del Valle is accounted for under the equity method. Equity income (loss)&#151;net includes our proportionate share of the results of Jugos del Valle's operations beginning November 2007
and is included in the Latin America operating segment. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
order to increase the efficiency of our bottling and distribution operations in the German market, the Company, through its consolidated German bottling operation
Coca-Cola Erfrischungsgetraenke AG ("CCEAG"), acquired 18 German bottling and distribution operations on September&nbsp;1, 2007, for a total purchase price of approximately
$547&nbsp;million plus transaction costs. Following the acquisition, the Company owns the franchise rights for all of the German market. The purchase price consisted of approximately
17&nbsp;percent of the outstanding shares of CCEAG valued at approximately $384&nbsp;million, approximately $151&nbsp;million in cash and assumed net debt of approximately $12&nbsp;million.
The acquisition agreements also provide the former owners of the 18 German bottling and distribution operations a put option to sell their respective shares in CCEAG back to the Company on
January&nbsp;2, 2014, with notification to the Company required by September&nbsp;30, 2013. In addition, the agreements provide the Company with a call option to repurchase the issued shares of
CCEAG back from the former owners of the 18 German bottling and distribution operations on January&nbsp;2, 2014, with notification to the former owners of the 18 German bottlers and distributors by
December&nbsp;15, 2013. The strike price of the call option is approximately 20&nbsp;percent higher than the strike price of the put option. As of the closing date of this transaction, the present
value of the amounts likely to be paid under the put and call agreements and guaranteed future cash payments was approximately $384&nbsp;million. Under the purchase method of accounting, the total
purchase price is allocated to the tangible assets, liabilities and identifiable intangible assets acquired based on their estimated fair values. Any excess of purchase price over the aggregate fair
value of acquired net assets is recorded as goodwill. The final purchase price allocated to franchise rights was approximately $345&nbsp;million; property, plant and equipment was approximately
$227&nbsp;million; deferred tax liabilities was approximately $97&nbsp;million; and goodwill was approximately $153&nbsp;million. Approximately $33&nbsp;million of the goodwill is deductible
for tax purposes. The franchise rights have been assigned an
indefinite life. In conjunction with this acquisition, management formulated a plan to improve the efficiency of the German bottling and distribution operations. The implementation of this plan
resulted in approximately $45&nbsp;million in liabilities for anticipated costs related to production and distribution facility closings. As of December&nbsp;31, 2008, the Company has implemented
a majority of its plan, and expects the final implementation steps to be completed by the end of the first quarter of 2009. This transaction was accounted for as a business combination, with the
results of the 18 German bottling and distribution operations included in the Bottling Investments operating segment since September&nbsp;1, 2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the third quarter of 2007, the Company acquired a 34&nbsp;percent interest in Tokyo CCBC. The Company's investment in Tokyo CCBC is accounted for under the equity method. Equity
income (loss)&#151;net includes our proportionate share of the results of Tokyo CCBC's operations beginning July 2007 and is included in the Bottling Investments operating segment. In the third
quarter of 2007, the Company also acquired an additional 11&nbsp;percent interest in NORSA. After this acquisition, the Company owned approximately 60&nbsp;percent of NORSA. The Company began
consolidating this entity from the date we acquired the additional 11&nbsp;percent interest. The </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>135</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=137,EFW="2190274",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=158175,FOLIO='135',FILE='DISK121:[09ZAL1.09ZAL74201]GE74201A.;20',USER='MSULLIV',CD='26-FEB-2009;11:54' -->
<A NAME="page_ge74201_1_136"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
THE COCA-COLA COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 20: ACQUISITIONS AND INVESTMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>combined
purchase price for these third-quarter acquisitions was approximately $203&nbsp;million. NORSA is included in the Bottling Investments operating segment. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
June&nbsp;7, 2007, in an effort to expand our still beverage offerings, our Company acquired Energy Brands&nbsp;Inc., also known as glac&eacute;au, the maker of enhanced
water brands, such as vitaminwater and smartwater, for approximately $4.1&nbsp;billion. On the acquisition date, we made a cash payment of approximately $2.9&nbsp;billion for a 71.4&nbsp;percent
interest in glac&eacute;au and entered into a put and call option agreement with certain entities associated with the Tata Group ("Tata") to acquire the remaining 28.6&nbsp;percent ownership
interest in glac&eacute;au. As a result of the terms of these agreements with Tata, the amount to be paid under the put and call option agreement of $1.2&nbsp;billion was recorded at the
acquisition date as an additional investment in glac&eacute;au, with the offset being recorded as a current liability within loans and notes payable on the consolidated balance sheets. On
October&nbsp;22, 2007, the Company exercised its right to call the remaining interest in glac&eacute;au and paid Tata $1.2&nbsp;billion, such that the Company owned 100&nbsp;percent of
glac&eacute;au as of December&nbsp;31, 2007. Under the purchase method of accounting, the total purchase price of glac&eacute;au is allocated to the tangible assets, liabilities and
identifiable intangible assets acquired based on their estimated fair values. Any excess of purchase price over the aggregate fair value of acquired net assets is recorded as goodwill. The final
purchase price allocation was approximately $3.3&nbsp;billion to trademarks, approximately $2.0&nbsp;billion to goodwill, approximately $0.1&nbsp;billion to customer relationships and
approximately $1.1&nbsp;billion to deferred tax liabilities. The trademarks have been assigned indefinite lives. The goodwill resulting from this acquisition is primarily related to our ability to
optimize the route to market and increase the availability of the product, which will result in additional product sales. The goodwill also includes the recognition of deferred tax liabilities
associated with the identifiable intangible assets recorded in purchase accounting. The goodwill is not deductible for tax purposes. On August&nbsp;30, 2007, the Company announced its plans to
transition to a new distribution model for glac&eacute;au products. This new distribution model includes a mix of legacy glac&eacute;au distributors and existing Coca-Cola
system bottlers. Also, the Company will retain the distribution rights for certain channels. The implementation of this plan resulted in approximately $0.2&nbsp;billion in liabilities for
anticipated costs to terminate existing glac&eacute;au distribution agreements, which was reflected as an adjustment to the original allocation of acquisition costs. Substantially all of these
termination costs were
paid by the end of 2008. The acquisition of glac&eacute;au was accounted for as a business combination, with the results of the acquired entity included in the North America operating segment
as of the acquisition date. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition, certain executive officers and former shareholders of glac&eacute;au invested approximately $179&nbsp;million of their proceeds from the sale of
glac&eacute;au in common stock of the Company at then-current market prices. These shares of Company common stock were placed in escrow pursuant to the glac&eacute;au
acquisition agreement. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
discussed below, in the second quarter of 2007, the Company divested a portion of its interest in Scarlet Ibis Investment 3 (Proprietary) Limited ("Scarlet"), a bottling company in
South Africa. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
the first quarter of 2007, our Company acquired the remaining 65&nbsp;percent interest in CCBPI from San Miguel Corporation ("SMC") for consideration of approximately
$591&nbsp;million plus assumed net debt, of which $100&nbsp;million was placed in escrow until certain matters related to the closing balance sheet audit of CCBPI were resolved. During the third
quarter of 2007, the entire escrow amount was released, and our Company recovered $70&nbsp;million. The adjusted purchase price after the recovery from escrow was approximately $521&nbsp;million
plus assumed debt, net of acquired cash, of approximately $79&nbsp;million. Of the $521&nbsp;million of consideration, the Company has outstanding notes payable to SMC of approximately
$100&nbsp;million as of </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>136</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=138,EFW="2190274",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=506778,FOLIO='136',FILE='DISK121:[09ZAL1.09ZAL74201]GE74201A.;20',USER='MSULLIV',CD='26-FEB-2009;11:54' -->
<A NAME="page_ge74201_1_137"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
THE COCA-COLA COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 20: ACQUISITIONS AND INVESTMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>December&nbsp;31,
2008. As a result of the acquisition, the Company owns 100&nbsp;percent of the outstanding stock of CCBPI. The final amount of purchase price allocated to property, plant and
equipment was approximately $319&nbsp;million; franchise rights was approximately $285&nbsp;million; and goodwill was approximately $199&nbsp;million. The goodwill is not deductible for tax
purposes. The franchise rights have been assigned an indefinite life. Management finalized a plan to improve the efficiency of CCBPI, which included the closing of eight production facilities during
the third quarter of 2007. The acquisition of CCBPI was accounted for as a business combination, with the results of the acquired entity included in the Bottling Investments operating segment as of
the acquisition date. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;First
quarter 2007 acquisition and investing activities also included approximately $327&nbsp;million related to the purchases of Fuze and Leao Junior&nbsp;S.A. ("Leao Junior"), a
Brazilian tea company, which are included in the North America and Latin America operating segments, respectively. The final amount of purchase price, related to these acquisitions, allocated to
property, plant and equipment was approximately $19&nbsp;million; identifiable intangible assets, primarily indefinite-lived trademarks, was approximately $265&nbsp;million; and goodwill was
approximately $57&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
acquisitions of the 18 German bottling and distribution operations, glac&eacute;au, CCBPI, Fuze, Leao Junior, NORSA, our 34&nbsp;percent investment in Tokyo CCBC and our
50&nbsp;percent investment in Jugos del Valle in 2007 were primarily financed through the issuance of commercial paper and long-term debt. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Assuming
the results of the businesses acquired in 2007 had been included in operations beginning on January&nbsp;1, 2006, the estimated pro forma net operating revenues of the Company
for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006 would have been approximately $29.6&nbsp;billion and $25.9&nbsp;billion, respectively. The estimated pro forma net income, excluding the
effect of interest expense as a result of financing the acquisitions, for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006 would not have been significantly different than the reported amounts. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2006, our Company's acquisition and investment activity, including the acquisition of trademarks, totaled approximately $901&nbsp;million. In the third quarter of 2006, our
Company acquired a controlling shareholding interest in Kerry Beverages Limited ("KBL"). KBL was formed by the Company and the Kerry Group in 1993 and has a majority ownership in 11
joint ventures that manufacture and distribute Company products across nine provinces in China. KBL also has a minority interest in the joint venture bottler in Beijing. Subsequent to the acquisition,
the Company changed KBL's name to Coca-Cola China Industries Limited ("CCCIL"). As a result of the transaction, the Company owned 89.5&nbsp;percent of the
outstanding shares of CCCIL. The Company purchased the remaining 10.5&nbsp;percent of the outstanding shares during the fourth quarter of 2008 at the same price per share as the initial purchase
price plus interest. This transaction was accounted for as a business combination, and the results of CCCIL's operations have been included in the Company's consolidated financial
statements since August&nbsp;29, 2006. CCCIL is included in the Bottling Investments operating segment. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the third quarter of 2006, our Company signed agreements with J. Bruce Llewellyn and Brucephil,&nbsp;Inc. ("Brucephil"), the parent company of The Philadelphia Coca-Cola
Bottling Company, for the potential purchase of the remaining shares of Brucephil not then owned by the Company. The agreements provide for the Company's purchase of the shares upon the election of
Mr.&nbsp;Llewellyn or the election of the Company. Based on the terms of these agreements, the Company concluded that it must consolidate Brucephil under Interpretation No.&nbsp;46(R) effective
September&nbsp;29, 2006. During the third quarter of 2008, the Company purchased all remaining shares not previously owned by the Company. As a result, the Company owned 100&nbsp;percent of
Brucephil as of </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>137</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=139,EFW="2190274",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=947779,FOLIO='137',FILE='DISK121:[09ZAL1.09ZAL74201]GE74201A.;20',USER='MSULLIV',CD='26-FEB-2009;11:54' -->
<A NAME="page_ge74201_1_138"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
THE COCA-COLA COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 20: ACQUISITIONS AND INVESTMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>December&nbsp;31,
2008. Brucephil's financial statements were consolidated effective September&nbsp;29, 2006 and included in our Bottling Investments operating segment. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Also
in the third quarter of 2006, our Company acquired Apollinaris&nbsp;GmbH ("Apollinaris"). Apollinaris has been selling sparkling and still mineral water in Germany since 1862.
This transaction was accounted for as a business combination, and the results of Apollinaris' operations have been included in the Company's consolidated financial statements since July&nbsp;1,
2006. A portion of Apollinaris' business is included in the Europe operating segment, and the balance is included in the Bottling Investments operating segment. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
combined amount paid to complete these third quarter 2006 transactions totaled approximately $718&nbsp;million. As a result of these transactions, the Company recorded
approximately $707&nbsp;million of franchise rights, approximately $74&nbsp;million of trademarks and approximately $182&nbsp;million of goodwill. The franchise rights and trademarks have been
assigned an indefinite life. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
January 2006, our Company acquired a 100&nbsp;percent interest in TJC Holdings (Pty)&nbsp;Ltd. ("TJC"), a bottling company in South Africa, from Chef Limited and Tom Cook Trust
for cash consideration of approximately $200&nbsp;million. Subsequently, the Company renamed TJC as Scarlet. This transaction was accounted for as a business combination, with the results of Scarlet
included in the Company's consolidated financial statements since the date of acquisition. In May 2007, Scarlet issued common shares to a Black Economic Empowerment Entity ("BEEE") at a price per
share equal to the current carrying value of our investment in Scarlet, which was subsequently renamed as Shanduka Beverages (Proprietary) Limited ("Shanduka"). This issuance reduced the Company's
ownership interest in Shanduka to 30&nbsp;percent. As a result of subordinated financial support provided by the Company for the BEEE to complete this transaction, the Company concluded that we must
continue to consolidate Shanduka's operations under Interpretation No.&nbsp;46(R). Shanduka is included in our Bottling Investments operating segment. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Assuming
the results of the businesses acquired in 2006 had been included in operations beginning on January&nbsp;1, 2006, pro forma financial data would not be required due to
immateriality. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTE 21: OPERATING SEGMENTS  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2008, the Company made certain changes to its operating structure to align geographic responsibility. The European Union operating segment was reconfigured to include the Adriatic
and Balkans business unit and was renamed the Europe operating segment; and the remaining Eurasia operating segment was combined with the Africa operating segment into the new Eurasia and Africa
operating segment. The changes in operating structure did not impact the other existing geographic operating segments, Bottling Investments or Corporate. As of December&nbsp;31, 2008, our
organizational structure consisted of the following operating segments: Eurasia and Africa; Europe; Latin America; North America; Pacific; Bottling Investments; and Corporate. Prior-period amounts
have been reclassified to conform to the new operating structure described above. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Segment Products and Services  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The business of our Company is nonalcoholic beverages. Our operating segments derive a majority of their revenues from the manufacture
and sale of beverage concentrates and syrups and, in some cases, the sale of finished beverages. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Method of Determining Segment Income or Loss  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management evaluates the performance of our operating segments separately to individually monitor the different factors affecting
financial performance. Our Company manages income taxes and financial costs, such as interest income and expense, on a global basis within the Corporate operating segment. We evaluate segment
performance based on income or loss before income taxes. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>138</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<TD COLSPAN=19 style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-left:8pt;text-indent:-8pt;"><FONT SIZE=1> <SUP>3</SUP></FONT><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;Equity income (loss)&#151;net and income (loss) before income taxes was reduced by approximately
$19&nbsp;million for Europe, $8&nbsp;million for North America and $1,659&nbsp;million for Bottling Investments, primarily attributable to our proportionate share of asset impairment charges recorded by equity method investees. Refer to Note&nbsp;3
and Note&nbsp;19.</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD COLSPAN=19 style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-top:9pt;margin-left:8pt;text-indent:-8pt;"><FONT SIZE=1> <SUP>4</SUP></FONT><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;Income (loss) before income taxes was reduced by approximately $2&nbsp;million for
North America, $30&nbsp;million for Bottling Investments and $52&nbsp;million for Corporate, primarily due to other-than-temporary impairments of available-for-sale securities. Refer to Note&nbsp;10 and Note&nbsp;19.</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD COLSPAN=19 style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-top:9pt;margin-left:8pt;text-indent:-8pt;"><FONT SIZE=1> <SUP>5</SUP></FONT><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;Income (loss) before income taxes was increased by approximately $119&nbsp;million
for Bottling Investments and Corporate, primarily due to the gain on the sale of Remil to Coca-Cola FEMSA and the sale of 49&nbsp;percent of our interest in Coca-Cola Pakistan to Coca-Cola Icecek. Refer to Note&nbsp;3.</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">

<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

approximately $37&nbsp;million for Eurasia and Africa, $33&nbsp;million for Europe, $4&nbsp;million for Latin America, $23&nbsp;million for North America, $3&nbsp;million for Pacific, $47&nbsp;million for Bottling Investments and $121&nbsp;million

<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD COLSPAN=19 style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-top:9pt;margin-left:8pt;text-indent:-8pt;"><FONT SIZE=1> <SUP>10</SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT SIZE=1>Equity income (loss)&#151;net and income (loss) before income taxes was decreased by approximately $150&nbsp;million
for Bottling Investments, primarily due to our proportionate share of asset impairments and restructuring costs, net of benefits from tax rate changes, recorded by equity method investees. Refer to Note&nbsp;19.</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD COLSPAN=19 style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-top:9pt;margin-left:8pt;text-indent:-8pt;"><FONT SIZE=1> <SUP>11</SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT SIZE=1>Income (loss) before income taxes was increased by $227&nbsp;million for Corporate primarily due to gains on the
sale of real estate in Spain and in the United States, the sale of our ownership in Vonpar and the sale of Coca-Cola Amatil shares. Refer to Note&nbsp;19.</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD COLSPAN=19 style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-top:9pt;margin-left:8pt;text-indent:-8pt;"><FONT SIZE=1> <SUP>12</SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT SIZE=1>Operating income (loss) and income (loss) before income taxes were reduced by approximately $3&nbsp;million for
Eurasia and Africa, $36&nbsp;million for Europe, $62&nbsp;million for the Pacific, $87&nbsp;million for Bottling Investments and $1&nbsp;million for Corporate primarily due to asset impairments, contract termination costs related to production
capacity efficiencies and other restructuring costs. Refer to Note&nbsp;19.</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD COLSPAN=19 style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-top:9pt;margin-left:8pt;text-indent:-8pt;"><FONT SIZE=1> <SUP>13</SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT SIZE=1>Operating income (loss) and income (loss) before income taxes were reduced by $100&nbsp;million for Corporate as a
result of a donation made to The Coca-Cola Foundation. Refer to Note&nbsp;19.</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD COLSPAN=19 style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-top:9pt;margin-left:8pt;text-indent:-8pt;"><FONT SIZE=1> <SUP>14</SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT SIZE=1>Equity income&#151;net and income (loss) before income taxes were reduced by approximately $587&nbsp;million for
Bottling Investments primarily related to our proportionate share of impairment and restructuring charges recorded by CCE which were partially offset by our proportionate share of changes in certain of CCE's state and Canadian federal and provincial
tax rates (refer to Note&nbsp;3 and Note&nbsp;19), and were reduced by approximately $19&nbsp;million due to our proportionate share of restructuring charges recorded by other equity method investees.</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD COLSPAN=19 style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-top:9pt;margin-left:8pt;text-indent:-8pt;"><FONT SIZE=1> <SUP>15</SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT SIZE=1>Income (loss) before income taxes was increased by approximately $298&nbsp;million for Corporate as a result of net
gains on the sale of Coca-Cola FEMSA shares and the sale of a portion of our investment in Coca-Cola Icecek in an initial public offering. Refer to Note&nbsp;19.</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_gi74201_1_141"> </A>


<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"Black" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"font-family:times;" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TABLESHADECOLOR,"#CCEEFF" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_STABLERULES,"border-bottom:solid #000000 1.0pt;" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DTABLERULES,"border-bottom:solid #000000 2.25pt;" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_SCRTABLERULES,"border-bottom:solid #000000 1.0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;" -->





<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DCRTABLERULES,"border-bottom:solid #000000 2.25pt;margin-bottom:0pt;" -->


<!-- PARA=JUSTIFY -->
</FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><I> <A NAME="gi74201_report_of_management_on_intern__rep04163"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_gi74201_1"> </A>
<BR>    </I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>  REPORT OF MANAGEMENT ON INTERNAL CONTROL OVER FINANCIAL REPORTING<BR>  </B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>The Coca-Cola Company and Subsidiaries    <BR>    </I></B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management of the Company is responsible for the preparation and integrity of the consolidated financial statements appearing in our
annual report on Form&nbsp;10-K. The financial statements were prepared in conformity with generally accepted accounting principles appropriate in the circumstances and, accordingly,
include certain amounts based on our best judgments and estimates. Financial information in this annual report on Form&nbsp;10-K is consistent with that in the financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management
of the Company is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as such term is defined in Rule&nbsp;13a-15(f)
under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act"). The Company's internal control over financial reporting is designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial
reporting and the preparation of the consolidated financial statements. Our internal control over financial reporting is supported by a program of internal audits and appropriate reviews by
management, written policies and guidelines, careful selection and training of qualified personnel and a written Code of Business Conduct adopted by our Company's Board of Directors, applicable to all
officers and employees of our Company and subsidiaries. In addition, our Company's Board of Directors adopted a written Code of Business Conduct for Non-Employee Directors which reflects
the same principles and values as our Code of Business Conduct for officers and employees but focuses on matters of most relevance to non-employee Directors. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Because
of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements and, even when determined to be effective, can only provide
reasonable assurance with respect to financial statement preparation and presentation. Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may
become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Audit Committee of our Company's Board of Directors, composed solely of Directors who are independent in accordance with the requirements of the New York Stock Exchange listing
standards, the Exchange Act and the Company's Corporate Governance Guidelines, meets with the independent auditors, management and internal auditors periodically to discuss internal control over
financial reporting and auditing and financial reporting matters. The Audit Committee reviews with the independent auditors the scope and results of the audit effort. The Audit Committee also meets
periodically with the independent auditors and the chief internal auditor without management present to ensure that the independent auditors and the chief internal auditor have free access to the
Audit Committee. Our Audit Committee's Report can be found in the Company's 2009 Proxy Statement. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management
assessed the effectiveness of the Company's internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2008. In making this assessment, management used the criteria
set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO) in </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Internal Control&#151;Integrated Framework</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. Based on
our assessment, management believes that the Company maintained effective internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2008. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's independent auditors, Ernst&nbsp;&amp; Young&nbsp;LLP, a registered public accounting firm, are appointed by the Audit Committee of the Company's Board of Directors,
subject to ratification by our Company's shareowners. Ernst&nbsp;&amp; Young&nbsp;LLP has audited and reported on the consolidated financial statements of The Coca-Cola Company and
subsidiaries and the Company's internal control over financial reporting. The reports of the independent auditors are contained in this annual report. </FONT></P>

<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=143,EFW="2190274",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=458082,FOLIO='141',FILE='DISK121:[09ZAL1.09ZAL74201]GI74201A.;26',USER='LPALLES',CD='26-FEB-2009;12:47' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_gk74201_1_142"> </A>


<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"Black" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"font-family:times;" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TABLESHADECOLOR,"#CCEEFF" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_STABLERULES,"border-bottom:solid #000000 1.0pt;" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DTABLERULES,"border-bottom:solid #000000 2.25pt;" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_SCRTABLERULES,"border-bottom:solid #000000 1.0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;" -->





<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DCRTABLERULES,"border-bottom:solid #000000 2.25pt;margin-bottom:0pt;" -->


<!-- PARA=JUSTIFY -->
</FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="gk74201_report_of_independent___gk702287"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_gk74201_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>  Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Board of Directors and Shareowners<BR>  </B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>The Coca-Cola Company  </I></B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of The Coca-Cola Company and subsidiaries as of December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007, and
the related consolidated statements of income, shareowners' equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2008. These financial statements are the
responsibility of the Company's management. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements based on our audits. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States). Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to
obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement. An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in
the financial statements. An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement
presentation. We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
our opinion, the financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the consolidated financial position of The Coca-Cola Company and
subsidiaries at December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007, and the consolidated results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2008, in
conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
discussed in Notes&nbsp;1 and 17 to the consolidated financial statements, in 2007 the Company adopted FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;48 related to accounting for uncertainty in
income taxes. Also as discussed in Notes&nbsp;1 and 16 to the consolidated financial statements, in 2006 the Company adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;158 related to defined benefit pension and other
postretirement plans. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), The Coca-Cola Company's internal control over
financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2008, based on criteria established in </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Internal Control&#151;Integrated Framework</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> issued by the
Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission and our report dated February&nbsp;26, 2009 expressed an unqualified opinion thereon. </FONT></P>

<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=144,EFW="2190274",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=1020022,FOLIO='142',FILE='DISK121:[09ZAL1.09ZAL74201]GK74201A.;12',USER='MSULLIV',CD='26-FEB-2009;11:54' -->

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_gm74201_1_143"> </A>


<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"Black" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"font-family:times;" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TABLESHADECOLOR,"#CCEEFF" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_STABLERULES,"border-bottom:solid #000000 1.0pt;" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DTABLERULES,"border-bottom:solid #000000 2.25pt;" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_SCRTABLERULES,"border-bottom:solid #000000 1.0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;" -->





<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DCRTABLERULES,"border-bottom:solid #000000 2.25pt;margin-bottom:0pt;" -->


<!-- PARA=JUSTIFY -->
</FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="gm74201_report_of_independent_register__rep04107"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_gm74201_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>  Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm<BR>  on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Board of Directors and Shareowners<BR>  </B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>The Coca-Cola Company  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have audited The Coca-Cola Company's internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2008, based on
criteria established in </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Internal Control&#151;Integrated Framework</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission
(the COSO criteria). The Coca-Cola Company's management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting, and for its assessment of the effectiveness of
internal control over financial reporting included in the accompanying Report of Management on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company's
internal control over financial reporting based on our audit. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States). Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to
obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects. Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control
over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk, and
performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances. We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A
company's internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of
financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. A company's internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures
that (1)&nbsp;pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2)&nbsp;provide
reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and
expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3)&nbsp;provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely
detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company's assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Because
of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements. Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future
periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
our opinion, The Coca-Cola Company maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2008, based on the
COSO criteria. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated balance sheets of The Coca-Cola
Company and subsidiaries as of December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007, and the related consolidated statements of income, shareowners' equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended
December&nbsp;31, 2008, and our report dated February&nbsp;26, 2009 expressed an unqualified opinion thereon. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our reporting period ends on the Friday closest to the last day of the quarterly calendar period. Our fiscal year ends on December&nbsp;31
regardless of the day of the week on which December&nbsp;31 falls. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's first quarter of 2008 results were impacted by one less shipping day as compared to the first quarter of 2007. Additionally, the Company recorded the following transactions
which impacted results: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Charges of approximately $2&nbsp;million for North America and $76&nbsp;million for Corporate, primarily due to
restructuring costs and asset write-downs. Refer to Note&nbsp;18 and Note&nbsp;19.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Equity income (loss)&#151;net was increased by approximately $5&nbsp;million for Bottling Investments due to our
proportionate share of one-time adjustments recorded by our equity method investees. Refer to Note&nbsp;19.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>A net tax charge of approximately $2&nbsp;million related to amounts required to be recorded for changes to our
uncertain tax positions under Interpretation No.&nbsp;48, including interest and penalties. Refer to Note&nbsp;17. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the second quarter of 2008, the Company recorded the following transactions which impacted results: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Charges of approximately $4&nbsp;million for North America, $5&nbsp;million for Bottling Investments and
$88&nbsp;million for Corporate, primarily due to restructuring costs, contract termination fees and asset impairments. Refer to Note&nbsp;18 and Note&nbsp;19.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Equity income (loss)&#151;net was reduced by approximately $1.1&nbsp;billion for Bottling Investments, primarily
as a result of our proportionate share of an impairment charge recorded by CCE. Refer to Note&nbsp;3 and Note&nbsp;19.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Other income (loss)&#151;net was increased by approximately $102&nbsp;million for Bottling Investments and
Corporate, primarily due to the gain on the sale of Remil to Coca-Cola FEMSA. Refer to Note&nbsp;19.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>A net tax charge of approximately $29&nbsp;million related to amounts required to be recorded for changes to our
uncertain tax positions under Interpretation No.&nbsp;48, including interest and penalties. Refer to Note&nbsp;17. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>An approximate $40&nbsp;million tax expense related to amounts required to be recorded for changes to our uncertain tax
positions under Interpretation No.&nbsp;48. Refer to Note&nbsp;17.  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>An income tax benefit of approximately $19&nbsp;million primarily related to asset write-downs and restructuring
activities in Eurasia and Africa, Europe, Latin America, North America, Pacific, Bottling Investments and Corporate. Refer to Note&nbsp;17. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>146</FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="gr74201_item_9._changes_in_and_disagre__ite03576"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_gr74201_1"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>  ITEM 9.&nbsp;&nbsp;CHANGES IN AND DISAGREEMENTS WITH ACCOUNTANTS ON ACCOUNTING AND FINANCIAL DISCLOSURE    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Not applicable.  </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="gr74201_item_9a._controls_and_procedures"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_gr74201_2"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>  ITEM 9A.&nbsp;&nbsp;CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company, under the supervision and with the participation of its management, including the Chief Executive Officer and the Chief
Financial Officer, evaluated the effectiveness of the design and operation of the Company's "disclosure controls and procedures" (as defined in Rule&nbsp;13a-15(e) under the Securities
Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the "Exchange Act")) as of the end of the period covered by this report. Based on that evaluation, the Chief Executive
Officer and the Chief Financial Officer concluded that the Company's disclosure controls and procedures were effective as of December&nbsp;31, 2008. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
report called for by Item&nbsp;308(a) of Regulation&nbsp;S-K is incorporated by reference to Report of Management on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting,
included in Part&nbsp;II, "Item&nbsp;8. Financial Statements and Supplementary Data" of this report. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
report called for by Item&nbsp;308(b) of Regulation&nbsp;S-K is incorporated by reference to Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm on Internal
Control Over Financial Reporting, included in Part&nbsp;II, "Item&nbsp;8. Financial Statements and Supplementary Data" of this report. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;There
has been no change in the Company's internal control over financial reporting during the quarter ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 that has materially affected, or is reasonably
likely to materially affect, the Company's internal control over financial reporting.  </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="gr74201_item_9b._other_information"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_gr74201_3"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>  ITEM 9B.&nbsp;&nbsp;OTHER INFORMATION    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Not applicable. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="gt74201_part_iii"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_gt74201_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>  PART III    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="gt74201_item_10._directors,_executive___ite02336"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_gt74201_2"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>  ITEM 10.&nbsp;&nbsp;DIRECTORS, EXECUTIVE OFFICERS AND CORPORATE GOVERNANCE    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The information under the subheadings "Board of Directors," "Section&nbsp;16(a) Beneficial Ownership Reporting Compliance,"
"Information About the Board of Directors and Corporate Governance &#151; The Audit Committee" and "Information About the Board of Directors and Corporate Governance &#151; The Board and
Board Committees" under the principal heading "ELECTION OF DIRECTORS" in the Company's 2009 Proxy Statement is incorporated herein by reference. See Item&nbsp;X in Part&nbsp;I of this report for
information regarding executive officers of the Company. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company has adopted a code of business conduct and ethics applicable to the Company's officers (including the Company's principal executive officer, principal financial officer and
controller) and employees, known as the Code of Business Conduct. In addition, the Company has adopted a Code of Business Conduct for Non-Employee Directors. Both Codes of Business Conduct
are available on the Company's website. In the event that we amend or waive any of the provisions of the Code of Business Conduct applicable to our principal executive officer, principal financial
officer or controller that relates to any element of the code of ethics definition enumerated in Item&nbsp;406(b) of Regulation&nbsp;S-K, we intend to disclose the same on the
Company's website at www.thecoca-colacompany.com. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
May&nbsp;14, 2008, we filed with the New York Stock Exchange ("NYSE") the Annual CEO Certification regarding the Company's compliance with the NYSE's corporate governance listing
standards as required by Section&nbsp;303A-12(a) of the NYSE Listed Company Manual. In addition, the Company has filed as exhibits to this annual report and to the annual report on
Form&nbsp;10-K for the fiscal year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007, the applicable certifications of its Chief Executive Officer and its Chief Financial Officer required under
Section&nbsp;302 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, regarding the quality of the Company's public disclosures.  </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="gt74201_item_11._executive_compensation"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_gt74201_3"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>  ITEM 11.&nbsp;&nbsp;EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The information under the principal headings "DIRECTOR COMPENSATION," "COMPENSATION DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS," "EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION,"
"REPORT OF THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE," and "COMPENSATION COMMITTEE INTERLOCKS AND INSIDER PARTICIPATION" in the Company's 2009 Proxy Statement is incorporated herein by reference. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="gt74201_item_12._security_ownership_of__ite04004"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_gt74201_4"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>  ITEM 12.&nbsp;&nbsp;SECURITY OWNERSHIP OF CERTAIN BENEFICIAL OWNERS AND MANAGEMENT AND RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The information under the principal heading "EQUITY COMPENSATION PLAN INFORMATION," and the information under the subheadings
"Ownership of Equity Securities of the Company" and "Principal Shareowners" below the principal heading "ELECTION OF DIRECTORS" in the Company's 2009 Proxy Statement is incorporated herein by
reference.  </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="gt74201_item_13._certain_relationships__ite03067"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_gt74201_5"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>  ITEM 13.&nbsp;&nbsp;CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED TRANSACTIONS, AND DIRECTOR INDEPENDENCE    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

Determinations" and "Certain Related Person Transactions" under the principal heading "ELECTION OF DIRECTORS" and the information under the principal headings "COMPENSATION COMMITTEE INTERLOCKS AND
INSIDER PARTICIPATION," and "COCA-COLA ENTERPRISES&nbsp;INC." in the Company's 2009 Proxy Statement is incorporated herein by reference.  </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>

following documents are filed as part of this report:

to Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm. </FONT></P>

of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting.  </FONT></P>

schedules for which provision is made in the applicable accounting regulations of the SEC are not required under the related instructions or are inapplicable and, therefore, have been omitted. </FONT></P>

</DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>3.</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Exhibits
</FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
</UL>
<UL>
<UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>In
reviewing the agreements included as exhibits to this report, please remember they are included to provide you with information regarding their terms and are not intended to provide any other
factual or disclosure information about the Company or the other parties to the agreements. The agreements contain representations and warranties by each of the parties to the applicable agreement.
These representations and warranties have been made solely for the benefit of the other parties to the applicable agreement and: </FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>should not in all instances be treated as categorical statements of fact, but rather as a way of allocating the risk to
one of the parties if those statements prove to be inaccurate;  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>may have been qualified by disclosures that were made to the other party in connection with the negotiation of the
applicable agreement, which disclosures are not necessarily reflected in the agreement;  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>may apply standards of materiality in a way that is different from what may be viewed as material to you or other
investors; and  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>were made only as of the date of the applicable agreement or such other date or dates as may be specified in the agreement
and are subject to more recent developments. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
</UL>
<UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Accordingly,
these representations and warranties may not describe the actual state of affairs as of the date they were made or at any other time. Additional information about the Company may be found
elsewhere in this report and the Company's other public filings, which are available without charge through the SEC's website at http://www.sec.gov. </FONT></P>

<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=162,EFW="2190274",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=843473,FOLIO='blank',FILE='DISK121:[09ZAL1.09ZAL74201]JO74201A.;1',USER='HYUNG',CD='26-FEB-2009;01:03' -->
